member.name: T:GSF.Collections.DoubleBufferedQueueManager`1
member.summary: Manages queues to reduce contention for a multithreaded, multiple-producer, single-consumer scenario.
member.remarks: For best results, each thread that is producing items to the consumer should call to receive a producer object that will not contend with any other producer. The consumer should either provide a handler to process the queued items or poll the manager by calling (not both!). It is not safe to use this class with multiple consumer threads.
member.typeparam: The types of items to be queued.
member.remarks: It is not safe to use this class with multiple consumer threads. The list returned by is not thread-safe and is reused on each Dequeue operation, so no other thread should access the list while another thread is calling Dequeue.

member.name: T:GSF.Collections.ListCollection`1
member.summary: A faster and functionally equivalent implementation of
member.typeparam: The type of the element in the collection

remarks.para: is based upon an . This means any simple call to the class is a function call that cannot be in-lined. This implementation forces the underlying item to be and shadows many of the methods to call instead of .
Since this class references the same underlying object, it can be successfully implemented as a or casted it its underlying type .

Profiling this class yield a ForEach loop and For loop that executes between 2-4 times faster than . This depends on the number of items in the list. The fewer the faster. Other operations such as Add/Insert/Remove are closer to 50% faster. Count is now in-lined (~20 times faster).
This performance is negated if accessing this class via the IList interface. When possible, use only strongly typed names.

member.name: M:GSF.Collections.PriorityQueue`1.AdjustPriority(System.Int32)
member.summary: Adds the given value to the priority of all values in the priority queue.
member.param: The amount by which to adjust priorities.
member.remarks: This allows for adjusting the priorities of all items in the heap without having to fix the heap each time a priority is changed. This can be useful to increase the priorities of items that have been in the queue for significant periods of time to prevent starvation. This is an O(n) operation.

member.name: T:GSF.Collections.DictionaryList`2
member.summary: Represents a sorted dictionary style list that supports .

remarks.para: Have you ever needed the quick look-up feature on a Dictionary (e.g., Hashtable), but ended up missing the indexed or sequential access like you have in a list? You may have wondered why the .NET dictionary class doesnt implement the IList interface which allows this. The reason IDictionary implementations do not normally implement the IList interface is because of ambiguity that is caused when implementing an integer key. For example, if you created a dictionary style class with a key of type "Integer" that actually did implement IList(Of T), you would not be able to access items in the IList interface by index without "casting" the class as IList. This is because the Item property in both the IDictionary and IList would have the same parameters. Note, however, that generics in .NET 2.0 gladly allow a class to implement both IDictionary and IList (even specifying as Integer as the key) so long you as you are happy knowing that the compiler will choose if you access your items by index or key. Given that caveat, there are many times when you need a dictionary style collection but also desire an IList implementation so the class can be used in other ways without conversion. As a result of these needs, weve added a generic class to code library called a DictionaryList -- which is essentially just a sorted dictionary style list (i.e., SortedList) that implements the IList(Of T) interface (specifically as IList(Of KeyValuePair(Of TKey, TValue))). You will find all of your convenient expected methods related to both dictionaries and lists; that is, you can look-up items by key or by index. The class works perfectly for any non-Integer based key (e.g., String, custom class, etc.) -- note that specifying an Integer as the key for the class wont cause an error, but it also will not be very useful. However, you can specify the key for your DictionaryList as a "Long," which allows you to use long integers for keyed look-ups and regular integers for indexed access--the best of both worlds! In summary, I would not change your programming habits to start using this for "my collection for everything," as nothing comes for free; however, if you have a need for a "hybrid" collection class, this fits the bill.

Important note about using an "Integer" as the key for this class: IDictionary implementations do not normally implement the IList interface because of ambiguity that is caused when implementing an integer key. For example, if you implement this class with a key of type "Integer" you will not be able to access items in the queue by index without "casting" the class as IList. This is because the Item property in both the IDictionary and IList would have the same parameters.

Note that prior to the addition of Generics in .NET, the class that performed a similar function was the "NameObjectCollectionBase" in the System.Collections.Specialized namespace which specifically allowed item access by either key or by index. This class is similar in function but instead is a generic class allowing use with any strongly typed key or value.

member.typeparam: Generic key type.
Generic value type.

member.name: T:GSF.Collections.DoubleBufferedQueue`1
member.summary: A thread-safe double-buffered queue that allows for low-contention item processing in single-producer, single-consumer scenarios.
member.typeparam: Type of items being queued.
member.remarks: It is not safe to use this class with multiple consumer threads. The method must be called by one thread at a time, and the consumer must not access a list returned by Dequeue after its next call to Dequeue.

member.name: E:GSF.Collections.DoubleBufferedQueue`1.ProcessException
member.summary: Event that is raised if an exception is encountered while attempting to processing an item in the .
member.remarks: Processing will not stop for any exceptions thrown by user processing function, but exceptions will be exposed through this event.

member.name: T:GSF.Collections.ProcessDictionary`2
member.summary: Represents a thread-safe (via locking) keyed collection of items, based on , that get processed on independent threads with a consumer provided function.
member.typeparam: Type of keys used to reference process items.
Type of values to process.

remarks.para: This class acts as a strongly-typed sorted dictionary of objects to be processed.
Note that the will not start processing until the Start method is called.
Because this represents a dictionary style collection, all keys must be unique.

Be aware that this class is based on a (i.e., a that implements ), and since items in this kind of list are automatically sorted, items will be processed in "sorted" order regardless of the order in which they are added to the list.

Important note about using an "Integer" as the key for this class: because the base class must implement IList, a normal dictionary cannot be used for the base class. IDictionary implementations do not normally implement the IList interface because of ambiguity that is caused when implementing an integer key. For example, if you implement this class with a key of type "Integer," you will not be able to access items in the by index without "casting" the as IList. This is because the Item property in both the IDictionary and IList would have the same parameters (see the class for more details.).

member.name: T:GSF.Collections.ProcessDictionary`2.ProcessItemFunctionSignature
member.summary: Function signature that defines a method to process a key and value one at a time.
member.param: key to be processed.
value to be processed.

remarks.para: Required unless is implemented.
Used when creating a to process one item at a time.
Asynchronous will process individual items on multiple threads

member.name: T:GSF.Collections.ProcessDictionary`2.CanProcessItemFunctionSignature
member.summary: Function signature that determines if a key and value can be currently processed.
member.param: key to be checked for processing availability.
value to be checked for processing availability.
member.returns: True, if key and value can be processed.

remarks.para: Implementation of this function is optional. It will be assumed that an item can be processed if this function is not defined
Items must eventually get to a state where they can be processed or they will remain in the indefinitely.
Note that when this function is implemented and = ManyAtOnce (i.e., is defined), then each item presented for processing must evaluate as "CanProcessItem = True" before any items are processed.

member.name: T:GSF.Collections.NamespaceDoc
member.summary: Contains classes and type extension functions related to any fundamental collection including thread based processing queues.

member.name: T:GSF.Collections.QueueThreadingMode
member.summary: Enumeration of possible threading modes.

member.name: F:GSF.Collections.QueueThreadingMode.Asynchronous
member.summary: Processes several items in the at once on different threads, where processing order is not important.

member.name: F:GSF.Collections.QueueThreadingMode.Synchronous
member.summary: Processes items in the one at a time on a single thread, where processing order is important.

member.name: T:GSF.Collections.QueueProcessingStyle
member.summary: Enumeration of possible processing styles.

member.name: F:GSF.Collections.QueueProcessingStyle.OneAtATime
member.summary: Defines processing delegate to process only one item at a time.
member.remarks: This is the typical when the is asynchronous.

member.name: F:GSF.Collections.QueueProcessingStyle.ManyAtOnce
member.summary: Defines processing delegate to process all currently available items in the . Items are passed into delegate as an array.
member.remarks: This is the optimal when the is synchronous.

member.name: T:GSF.Collections.RequeueReason
member.summary: Enumeration of possible requeue reasons.

member.name: F:GSF.Collections.RequeueReason.CannotProcess
member.summary: Requeuing item since it cannot be processed at this time.

member.name: F:GSF.Collections.RequeueReason.Exception
member.summary: Requeuing item due to an exception.

member.name: F:GSF.Collections.RequeueReason.Timeout
member.summary: Requeing item due to timeout.

member.name: T:GSF.Collections.RequeueMode
member.summary: Enumeration of possible requeue modes.

member.name: F:GSF.Collections.RequeueMode.Prefix
member.summary: Requeues item at the beginning of the .

member.name: F:GSF.Collections.RequeueMode.Suffix
member.summary: Requeues item at the end of the .

member.name: T:GSF.Collections.ProcessQueue`1
member.summary: Represents a thread-safe (via locking) list of items, based on , that get processed on independent threads with a consumer provided function.
member.typeparam: Type of object to process

remarks.para: This class acts as a strongly-typed collection of objects to be processed.
Note that the will not start processing until the Start method is called.

member.name: F:GSF.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.DefaultProcessInterval
member.summary: Default processing interval (in milliseconds).

member.name: F:GSF.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.DefaultMaximumThreads
member.summary: Default maximum number of processing threads.

member.name: F:GSF.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.DefaultProcessTimeout
member.summary: Default processing timeout (in milliseconds).

member.name: F:GSF.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.DefaultRequeueOnTimeout
member.summary: Default setting for requeuing items on processing timeout.

member.name: F:GSF.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.DefaultRequeueOnException
member.summary: Default setting for requeuing items on processing exceptions.

member.name: F:GSF.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.RealTimeProcessInterval
member.summary: Default real-time processing interval (in milliseconds).

member.name: F:GSF.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.DefaultRequeueModeOnTimeout
member.summary: Default setting for requeuing mode on processing timeout.

member.name: F:GSF.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.DefaultRequeueModeOnException
member.summary: Default setting for requeuing mode on processing exceptions.

member.name: T:GSF.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.ProcessItemFunctionSignature
member.summary: Function signature that defines a method to process items one at a time.
member.param: Item to be processed.

remarks.para: Required unless is implemented.
Creates an asynchronous to process individual items - one item at a time - on multiple threads.

member.name: T:GSF.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.ProcessItemsFunctionSignature
member.summary: Function signature that defines a method to process multiple items at once.
member.param: Items to be processed.

remarks.para: Required unless is implemented.
Creates an asynchronous to process groups of items simultaneously on multiple threads.

member.name: T:GSF.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.CanProcessItemFunctionSignature
member.summary: Function signature that determines if an item can be currently processed.
member.param: Item to be checked for processing availability.
member.returns: True, if item can be processed. The default is true.

remarks.para: Implementation of this function is optional. It is assumed that an item can be processed if this function is not defined
Items must eventually get to a state where they can be processed, or they will remain in the indefinitely.

Note that when this function is implemented and ProcessingStyle = ManyAtOnce (i.e., is defined), then each item presented for processing must evaluate as "CanProcessItem = True" before any items are processed.

member.name: E:GSF.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.ItemProcessed
member.summary: Event that is raised after an item has been successfully processed.

remarks.para: Allows custom handling of successfully processed items.
Allows notification when an item has completed processing in the allowed amount of time, if a process timeout is specified.
Raised only when ProcessingStyle = OneAtATime (i.e., is defined).

member.name: E:GSF.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.ItemsProcessed
member.summary: Event that is raised after an array of items have been successfully processed.

remarks.para: Allows custom handling of successfully processed items.
Allows notification when an item has completed processing in the allowed amount of time, if a process timeout is specified.
Raised only when when ProcessingStyle = ManyAtOnce (i.e., is defined).

member.name: E:GSF.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.ItemTimedOut
member.summary: Event that is raised if an item's processing time exceeds the specified process timeout.

remarks.para: Allows custom handling of items that took too long to process.
Raised only when ProcessingStyle = OneAtATime (i.e., is defined).

member.name: E:GSF.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.ItemsTimedOut
member.summary: Event that is raised if the processing time for an array of items exceeds the specified process timeout.

remarks.para: Allows custom handling of items that took too long to process.
Raised only when ProcessingStyle = ManyAtOnce (i.e., is defined).

member.name: E:GSF.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.ProcessException
member.summary: Event that is raised if an exception is encountered while attempting to processing an item in the .
member.remarks: Processing will not stop for any exceptions thrown by the user function, but any captured exceptions will be exposed through this event.

member.name: P:GSF.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.ProcessingIsRealTime
member.summary: Gets indicator that items will be processed in real-time.

member.name: P:GSF.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.ThreadingMode
member.summary: Gets the current for the (i.e., synchronous or asynchronous).

remarks.para: The maximum number of processing threads determines the .
If the maximum threads are set to one, item processing will be synchronous (i.e., ThreadingMode = Synchronous).
If the maximum threads are more than one, item processing will be asynchronous (i.e., ThreadingMode = Asynchronous).

Note that for asynchronous , the processing interval will control how many threads are spawned at once. If items are processed faster than the specified processing interval, only one process thread will ever be spawned at a time. To ensure multiple threads are utilized to items, lower the process interval (minimum process interval is 1 millisecond).

member.name: P:GSF.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.ProcessingStyle
member.summary: Gets the item for the (i.e., one at a time or many at once).

remarks.para: The implemented item processing function determines the .

If the is ManyAtOnce, all available items in the are presented for processing at each processing interval. If you expect items to be processed in the order in which they were received, make sure you use a synchronous . Real-time are inherently synchronous.

member.name: P:GSF.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.ProcessInterval

member.name: M:GSF.Collections.ProcessQueue`1.Flush
member.summary: Blocks the current thread, if the is active (i.e., user has called "Start" method), until all items in are processed, and then stops the .

remarks.para: Begins processing items as quickly as possible, regardless of currently defined process interval, until all items in the have been processed. Stops the when this function ends. This method is typically called on shutdown to make sure any remaining queued items get processed before the is destructed.

It is possible for items to be added to the while the flush is executing. The flush will continue to process items as quickly as possible until the is empty. Unless the user stops queuing items to be processed, the flush call may never return (not a happy situation on shutdown). For this reason, during this function call, requeuing of items on exception or process timeout is temporarily disabled.
The does not clear queue prior to destruction. If the user fails to call this method before the class is destructed, there may be items that remain unprocessed in the .

member.summary: Notifies queue that data was added and/or modified, so it can begin processing data.

remarks.para: Derived classes *must* make sure to call this method after data gets added, so that the process timer can be enabled for intervaled and data processing can begin.
To make sure items in the always get processed, this function is expected to be invoked from within a SyncLock of the exposed SyncRoot (i.e., InternalList).

member.name: F:GSF.Common.IsPosixEnvironment
member.summary: Determines if the current system is a POSIX style environment.

remarks.para: Since a .NET application compiled under Mono can run under both Windows and Unix style platforms, you can use this property to easily determine the current operating environment.

This property will return true for both MacOSX and Unix environments. Use the Platform property of the to determine more specific platform type, e.g., MacOSX or Unix. Note that all flavors of Linux will show up as .

member.name: F:GSF.Common.IsMono
member.summary: Determines if the code base is currently running under Mono.
member.remarks: This property can be used to make a run-time determination if Windows or Mono based .NET is being used. However, it is highly recommended to use the MONO compiler directive wherever possible instead of determining this at run-time.

Returned if expression evaluates to True.
Returned if expression evaluates to False.
member.typeparam: Return type used for immediate expression

remarks.para: This function acts as a strongly-typed immediate if (a.k.a. inline if).

It is expected that this function will only be used in languages that do not support ?: conditional operations, e.g., Visual Basic.NET. In Visual Basic this function can be used as a strongly-typed IIf replacement by specifying "Imports GSF.Common".

member.name: M:GSF.Common.CreateArray``1(System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a strongly-typed Array.
member.returns: New array of specified type.
member.param: Desired length of new array.
member.typeparam: Return type for new array.

remarks.para: It is expected that this function will only be used in Visual Basic.NET.

The Array.CreateInstance provides better performance and more direct CLR access for array creation (not to mention less confusion on the matter of array lengths) in VB.NET, however the returned System.Array is not typed properly. This function properly casts the return array based on the type specification helping when Option Strict is enabled.

example.code: Dim buffer As Byte() = CreateArray(Of Byte)(12) Dim matrix As Integer()() = CreateArray(Of Integer())(10)

member.typeparam: Return type for new array.
member.remarks: It is expected that this function will only be used in Visual Basic.NET.

example.code: Dim elements As Integer() = CreateArray(12, -1) Dim names As String() = CreateArray(100, "undefined")

member.summary: Queries database and returns a single modeled table record for the specified .
member.param: Record restriction to apply.
member.returns: A single modeled table record for the queried record.
member.remarks: If no record is found for specified , null will be returned.

member.name: M:GSF.Data.Model.ITableOperations.QueryRecord(System.String,System.Object[])
member.summary: Queries database and returns a single modeled table record for the specified SQL filter expression and parameters.
member.param: Filter SQL expression for restriction as a composite format string - does not include WHERE. When escaping is needed for field names, use standard ANSI quotes.
Restriction parameter values.
member.returns: A single modeled table record for the queried record.

remarks.para: If no record is found for specified filter expression and parameters, null will be returned.

Each indexed parameter, e.g., "{0}", in the composite format will be converted into query parameters where each of the corresponding values in the collection will be applied as values to an executed query.
If needed, field names that are escaped with standard ANSI quotes in the filter expression will be updated to reflect what is defined in the user model.

member.returns: An enumerable of modeled table row instances for queried records.
member.remarks: If no record or is provided, all rows will be returned.

member.name: T:GSF.Data.Model.AmendExpressionAttribute
member.summary: Defines an attribute that will request amendment of a table name or field list with the specified text.

remarks.para: As an example, this can be used to add table hints, e.g., WITH (NOLOCK), for select statements in SQL Server.

Applying the to a modeled table with no specified database type parameter will be meant to infer that the amendment be used for all database types. Using a specific database type as a parameter to the attribute, e.g., [AmendExpression("WITH (NOLOCK)", DatabaseType.SQLServer)], means the amendment text will only be applied to the specific database - however, the attribute allows multiple instances on the same identifier so you could specify that amendment application only be applied to two databases:
[AmendExpression("AS T1", DatabaseType.SQLServer), AmendExpression("AS T1", DatabaseType.MySQL)]
Other parameters exist to fully customize target expression, set affix position and specify statement types:
[AmendExpression("TOP 200", TargetExpression = TargetExpression.FieldList, AffixPosition = AffixPosition.Prefix, StatementTypes = StatementTypes.SelectSet)]

member.summary: Gets or sets location for amendment application; defaults to .

member.remarks: When value is null, amendment text will be applied to all database types.

member.name: T:GSF.Data.Model.UseEscapedNameAttribute
member.summary: Defines an attribute that will request use of the escaped name of a modeled identifier, i.e., a table or field name. Typically needed when identifier names are reserved SQL key words.
member.remarks: Applying [UseEscapedName] to a modeled table or field with no parameters will specify that an escaped name be used for all database types. Using a specific database type as a parameter to the attribute, e.g., [UseEscapedName(DatabaseType.SQLServer)], means the escaped name will only be applied to the specific database - however, the attribute allows multiple instances on the same identifier so you could specify that escaping only be applied to two databases, for example: [UseEscapedName(DatabaseType.SQLServer), UseEscapedName(DatabaseType.MySQL)]. In the event multiple attributes have been applied to a modeled identifier where one instance has specified no target database type and others have, the system will assume to target all databases for escaping the name and ignore the specific targets.

member.name: P:GSF.Data.Model.UseEscapedNameAttribute.TargetDatabaseType
member.summary: Gets target for using escaped name.
member.remarks: When value is null, escaped name will be applied to all database types.

member.name: P:GSF.Data.Model.UseEscapedNameAttribute.UseAnsiQuotes
member.summary: Gets or sets flag that determines if double quotes should be used as the identifier delimiter, per SQL-99 standard, regardless of database type. Defaults to true except for MySQL.
member.remarks: If true, ANSI standard double-quotes will be used for escaping the identifier; otherwise, the escaping identifier will be based on the connected database type.

member.summary: Creates a new that will request use of escaped name for any database.

member.summary: Creates a new that will request use of escaped name for the specified .
member.param: Target for escaping identifier.

member.name: M:GSF.Data.Model.RecordRestriction.op_Addition(GSF.Data.Model.RecordRestriction,GSF.Data.Model.RecordRestriction)
member.summary: Combines two record restrictions with an AND condition.
member.param: left operand.
right operand.
member.returns: New combined record restriction.
member.remarks: If both parameters are null, result will be null. If one parameter is null and the other parameter is not, the non-null parameter will be returned. Equally, if the of both parameters are null, empty or only whitespace, then the result will be null. If one parameter has a filter expression that is null, empty or whitespace and the other parameter's filter expression is defined, then the parameter that has a filter expression will be returned.

member.name: T:GSF.Data.AdoDataConnection
member.summary: Creates a new from any specified or configured ADO.NET data source.
member.remarks:
Example connection and data provider strings:
Database type Example connection string / data provider string
SQL Server
ConnectionString = "Data Source=serverName; Initial Catalog=databaseName; User ID=userName; Password=password"
DataProviderString = "AssemblyName={System.Data, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b77a5c561934e089}; ConnectionType=System.Data.SqlClient.SqlConnection; AdapterType=System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDataAdapter"
Oracle
ConnectionString = "Data Source=tnsName; User ID=schemaUserName; Password=schemaPassword"
DataProviderString = "AssemblyName={Oracle.DataAccess, Version=2.112.2.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=89b483f429c47342}; ConnectionType=Oracle.DataAccess.Client.OracleConnection; AdapterType=Oracle.DataAccess.Client.OracleDataAdapter"
MySQL
ConnectionString = "Server=serverName; Database=databaseName; Uid=root; Pwd=password; allow user variables = true"
DataProviderString = "AssemblyName={MySql.Data, Version=6.3.6.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=c5687fc88969c44d}; ConnectionType=MySql.Data.MySqlClient.MySqlConnection; AdapterType=MySql.Data.MySqlClient.MySqlDataAdapter"
SQLite
ConnectionString = "Data Source=databaseName.db; Version=3; Foreign Keys=True; FailIfMissing=True"
DataProviderString = "AssemblyName={System.Data.SQLite, Version=1.0.99.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=db937bc2d44ff139}; ConnectionType=System.Data.SQLite.SQLiteConnection; AdapterType=System.Data.SQLite.SQLiteDataAdapter"
SQLite (Mono native driver)
ConnectionString = "Data Source=./databaseName.db; Version=3; Foreign Keys=True; FailIfMissing=True"
DataProviderString = "AssemblyName={Mono.Data.Sqlite, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=0738eb9f132ed756}; ConnectionType=Mono.Data.Sqlite.SqliteConnection; AdapterType=Mono.Data.Sqlite.SqliteDataAdapter"
Access / OleDB
ConnectionString = "Provider=Microsoft.Jet.OLEDB.4.0; Data Source=databaseName.mdb"
DataProviderString = "AssemblyName={System.Data, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b77a5c561934e089}; ConnectionType=System.Data.OleDb.OleDbConnection; AdapterType=System.Data.OleDb.OleDbDataAdapter"
ODBC Connection
ConnectionString = "Driver={SQL Server Native Client 10.0}; Server=serverName; Database=databaseName; Uid=userName; Pwd=password"
DataProviderString = "AssemblyName={System.Data, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b77a5c561934e089}; ConnectionType=System.Data.Odbc.OdbcConnection; AdapterType=System.Data.Odbc.OdbcDataAdapter"
Example configuration file that defines connection settings:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <configuration> <configSections> <section name="categorizedSettings" type="GSF.Configuration.CategorizedSettingsSection, GSF.Core" /> </configSections> <categorizedSettings> <systemSettings> <add name="ConnectionString" value="Data Source=localhost\SQLEXPRESS; Initial Catalog=MyDatabase; Integrated Security=SSPI" description="ADO database connection string" encrypted="false" /> <add name="DataProviderString" value="AssemblyName={System.Data, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b77a5c561934e089}; ConnectionType=System.Data.SqlClient.SqlConnection; AdapterType=System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDataAdapter" description="ADO database provider string" encrypted="false" /> </systemSettings> </categorizedSettings> <startup> <supportedRuntime version="v4.0" sku=".NETFramework,Version=v4.5" /> </startup> </configuration>

member.remarks: This value is automatically assigned based on the adapter type specified in the data provider string, however, if the database type cannot be determined it will be set to . In this case, if you know the behavior of your custom ADO database connection matches that of another defined database type, you can manually assign the database type to allow for database interaction interoperability.

member.name: T:GSF.Diagnostics.LogPublisher
member.summary: A publisher of log messages.
member.remarks:
and can be modified so messages that are generated with this instance will have this data appended to the log message.
The user can either call one of the Publish overloads to lazily publish a message, or they can register a message with RegisterEvent so calling this message will incur little overhead. If registering an event, the user can check to determine if the log message can be skipped altogether. Registering events also allows the user to specify the auto-suppression algorithm and the depth of the stack trace that will be recorded on a message being raised.

member.name: F:GSF.Diagnostics.LogPublisher.m_logger
member.summary: Occurs when a new is ready to be published.

member.name: F:GSF.Diagnostics.LogPublisher.InitialStackMessages
member.summary: The stack messages that existed when this publisher was created. This can be modified by the user of this publisher. Any messages that get published by this class will automatically have this data added to the log message.

member.name: F:GSF.Diagnostics.LogPublisher.InitialStackTrace
member.summary: The stack trace that existed when this publisher was created. This can be modified by the user of this publisher. Any messages that get published by this class will automatically have this data added to the log message.

member.name: P:GSF.Diagnostics.LogPublisher.MaxDistinctEventPublisherCount
member.summary: The maximum number of distinct events that this publisher can generate. (Default: 20)
member.remarks:
Since message suppression and collection occurs at the event name level, it is important to have only a few distinct message types. This is the limit so misapplication of this publisher will not cause memory impacts on the system.
It is recommended to keep the event name as a fixed string and not report any other meta data with the event.

member.name: F:GSF.Diagnostics.LogPublisher.m_lookupEventPublishers
member.summary: Where the s of specific events are cached.

member.name: T:GSF.Diagnostics.MessageClass
member.summary: Gets the classification of the message.

member.name: F:GSF.Diagnostics.MessageClass.Component
member.summary: Messages that come from core components. These messages are for classes that are not working towards a specific framework or application, but can generally be used.

member.name: F:GSF.Diagnostics.MessageClass.Framework
member.summary: Messages from higher level software components. A framework is what makes the underlying application work and is the assimilation of components for a specific purpose. Use this if the intent is that this code will be shared among many different applications and may be implemented differently in those applications. This is different from Component as it has a more specific and defined purpose.

member.name: F:GSF.Diagnostics.MessageClass.Application
member.summary: These messages are for the highest layer of an application. Messages like 'Application X is starting up, shutting down' would go here.

member.name: T:GSF.Diagnostics.MessageFlags
member.summary: Various flags that can be attributed to a .

member.name: F:GSF.Diagnostics.MessageFlags.None
member.summary: No flags are specified.

member.name: F:GSF.Diagnostics.MessageFlags.UsageIssue
member.summary: Indicates that a segment of code is not being used properly or ideally.

member.name: F:GSF.Diagnostics.MessageFlags.BugReport
member.summary: Indicates that a bug in the code exists somewhere. This is helpful when the programmer suspects that certain exceptions were not properly handled.

member.name: F:GSF.Diagnostics.MessageFlags.PerformanceIssue
member.summary: A flag indicating that a performance related issue has occurred.

member.name: F:GSF.Diagnostics.MessageFlags.SecurityMessage
member.summary: Indicates this message has security implications with it. Such as a successful/unsuccessful authentication.

member.name: F:GSF.Diagnostics.MessageFlags.SystemHealth
member.summary: These messages in generally should always be logged because they report the state of the current system's health. Normally this will be when the system health is abnormal, for example, something abnormal is happening in the background that is important to note and can assist debugging other components. Messages raised here would include First Chance Exceptions and exceptions in log message routing (such as Message Suppression).

member.name: T:GSF.Diagnostics.MessageLevel
member.summary: The level of importance of a message that is being raised. Increasing from Debug, Info, Warning, Error, Critical. None can be specified, but this indicates an importance level cannot be properly identified, and the message will be routed based on .

member.name: F:GSF.Diagnostics.MessageLevel.NA
member.summary: Indicates a level that cannot be generally subscribed to. In this case, the message can only be subscribed to if a is subscribed to. Example: First Chance AppDomain Exceptions could fall under here because it's impossible to assign the risk of this king of exception. Instead the SystemHealth flag will be raised.

member.name: F:GSF.Diagnostics.MessageLevel.Debug
member.summary: Indicates a message that may assist in debugging code and generally serves no additional purpose.

member.name: F:GSF.Diagnostics.MessageLevel.Info
member.summary: Indicates that the message is informational. No action should be taken for these type of messages.

member.name: F:GSF.Diagnostics.MessageLevel.Warning
member.summary: Indicates that something happened that might adversely affect the system's operation. This level can also be used for expected errors. Warnings can be precursors to errors in the system.

member.name: F:GSF.Diagnostics.MessageLevel.Error
member.summary: Indicates that something happened that might adversely affect the system's operation. This level should be reserved for errors that are not expected to occur. These are non-urgent failures to the system.

member.name: F:GSF.Diagnostics.MessageLevel.Critical
member.summary: Indicates that something happened that will render certain components useless. These errors can be recovered from. An example case would be one of those "this should never happen" errors that were likely not handled properly and thus could eventually make the system unstable or unusable.

member.name: T:GSF.Diagnostics.MessageLevelFlags
member.summary: The level of importance of a message that is being raised. Increasing from Debug, Info, Warning, Error, Critical. None can be specified, but this indicates an importance level cannot be properly identified, and the message will be routed based on .

member.name: F:GSF.Diagnostics.MessageLevelFlags.NA
member.summary: Indicates a level that cannot be generally subscribed to. In this case, the message can only be subscribed to if a is subscribed to. Example: First Chance AppDomain Exceptions could fall under here because it's impossible to assign the risk of this king of exception. Instead the SystemHealth flag will be raised.

member.name: F:GSF.Diagnostics.MessageLevelFlags.Debug
member.summary: Indicates a message that may assist in debugging code and generally serves no additional purpose.

member.name: F:GSF.Diagnostics.MessageLevelFlags.Info
member.summary: Indicates that the message is informational. No action should be taken for these type of messages.

member.name: F:GSF.Diagnostics.MessageLevelFlags.Warning
member.summary: Indicates that something happened that might adversely affect the system's operation. This level can also be used for expected errors. Warnings can be precursors to errors in the system.

member.name: F:GSF.Diagnostics.MessageLevelFlags.Error
member.summary: Indicates that something happened that might adversely affect the system's operation. This level should be reserved for errors that are not expected to occur. These are non-urgent failures to the system.

member.name: F:GSF.Diagnostics.MessageLevelFlags.Critical
member.summary: Indicates that something happened that will render certain components useless. These errors can be recovered from. An example case would be one of those "this should never happen" errors that were likely not handled properly and thus could eventually make the system unstable or unusable.

member.name: T:GSF.Diagnostics.ThreadPoolTrace
member.summary: Executes a trace on the for all callbacks currently queued. This will not include work items that have a time delayed callback.
member.remarks:
This class heavily relies on reflection to get the ThreadPool queue. Therefore it is very unlikely to work in MONO and can break if Microsoft changes any of the member names or how the ThreadPool works.
In this case will be set to false and will return "Not Supported"

member.name: P:GSF.Diagnostics.ThreadPoolTrace.WorksInThisRuntime
member.summary: Indicates that this trace works in the runtime version of .NET.

member.name: M:GSF.Diagnostics.ThreadPoolTrace.GetTrace(System.Text.StringBuilder)
member.summary: Traces all queued items on the ThreadPool.

member.name: T:GSF.Diagnostics.TimerTrace
member.summary: Executes a trace on the for all queued timers.
member.remarks:
This class heavily relies on reflection to get the Timer queue. Therefore it is very unlikely to work in MONO and can break if Microsoft changes any of the member names or how the Timer works.
In this case will be set to false and will return "Not Supported"

member.summary: Indicates that this trace works in the runtime version of .NET.

member.returns: A object representing the newly created process.

member.name: M:GSF.Identity.UserAccountControl.CreateProcessAsStandardUser(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a process under the standard user if the current process is elevated. The identity of the standard user is determined by retrieving the user token of the currently running Explorer (shell) process.
member.param: The path to the executable file.
The command-line arguments to pass to the process.
member.returns: A object representing the newly created process.

remarks.para: This method requires administrative privileges. An exception will be thrown if the current user is not elevated.

This is an especially useful function if you are trying to shell an application from an installation program. With UAC enabled, an application spawned from a setup program will be the "NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM" user - not the local user that executed the installer; this can wreak havoc if the spawned application needs to authenticate the local user.

member.name: P:GSF.Identity.UserAccountControl.IsUserAdmin
member.summary: Returns true if the current user has administrator privileges.
member.remarks: If UAC is on, then this property will return true even if the current process is not running elevated. If UAC is off, then this property will return true if the user is part of the built-in Administrators group.

member.name: P:GSF.Identity.UserAccountControl.IsUacEnabled
member.summary: Returns true if User Account Control (UAC) is enabled on this machine.
member.remarks: This value is obtained by checking the LUA registry key. It is possible that the user has not restarted the machine after enabling/disabling UAC. In that case, the value of the registry key does not reflect the true state of affairs.

member.name: P:GSF.Identity.UserAccountControl.IsCurrentProcessVirtualized
member.summary: Returns true if the current process is using UAC virtualization.
member.remarks: Under UAC virtualization, file system and registry accesses to specific locations performed by an application are redirected to provide backwards compatibility. 64-bit applications or applications that have an associated manifest do not enjoy UAC virtualization because they are assumed to be compatible with Vista and UAC.

member.name: P:GSF.Identity.UserAccountControl.IsCurrentProcessElevated
member.summary: Returns true if the current process is elevated, i.e. if the process went through an elevation consent phase.
member.remarks: This property will return false if UAC is disabled and the process is running as admin. It only determines whether the process went through the elevation procedure.

member.name: M:GSF.Identity.UserAccountControl.DisableUac
member.summary: Disables User Account Control by changing the LUA registry key. The changes do not have effect until the system is restarted.

member.name: M:GSF.Identity.UserAccountControl.DisableUacAndRestartWindows
member.summary: Disables User Account Control and restarts the system.

member.name: M:GSF.Identity.UserAccountControl.EnableUac
member.summary: Enables User Account Control by changing the LUA registry key. The changes do not have effect until the system is restarted.

member.name: M:GSF.Identity.UserAccountControl.EnableUacAndRestartWindows
member.summary: Enables User Account Control and restarts the system.

member.name: P:GSF.Identity.UserInfo.Exists
member.summary: Gets flag that determines if user exists.
member.returns: true if user is found to exist; otherwise false.

remarks.para: Unlike other properties in this class, will still work even if the domain server is unavailable. Calling this property without access to a domain server will return true if the user is authenticated. This only succeeds if the current user is the same as the , there is no way to determine if a user other than the currently authenticated user exists without access to the domain server. Local accounts are not subject to these constraints since the domain server will effectively be your local computer which is always accessible.

If a laptop user that's normally connected to the domain takes their computer on the road without VPN or other connectivity to the domain, the user can still login to the laptop using cached credentials therefore they are still considered to exist. Without access to the domain, no user information will be available (such as the listing) - if this data is needed offline it will need to be cached by the application in anticipation of offline access.

member.summary: Contains classes used to handle interoperability with older legacy applications.

member.name: T:GSF.Interop.VBArrayDescriptor
member.summary: Represents an old style Visual Basic array descriptor.
member.remarks: This class is used to mimic the binary array descriptor used when an array is serialized into a file using older Visual Basic applications (VB 6 and prior), this way old VB apps can still deserialize an array stored in a file written by a .NET application and vice versa.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.LOGON32_PROVIDER_DEFAULT
member.summary: Use the standard logon provider for the system. The default security provider is NTLM.

member.summary: This logon type is intended for high performance servers to authenticate plaintext passwords. The LogonUserEx function does not cache credentials for this logon type.

member.name: T:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS
member.summary: Win32 TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS enumeration.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenUser
member.summary: The buffer receives a TOKEN_USER structure that contains the user account of the token.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenGroups
member.summary: The buffer receives a TOKEN_GROUPS structure that contains the group accounts associated with the token.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenPrivileges
member.summary: The buffer receives a TOKEN_PRIVILEGES structure that contains the privileges of the token.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenOwner
member.summary: The buffer receives a TOKEN_OWNER structure that contains the default owner security identifier (SID) for newly created objects.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenPrimaryGroup
member.summary: The buffer receives a TOKEN_PRIMARY_GROUP structure that contains the default primary group SID for newly created objects.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenDefaultDacl
member.summary: The buffer receives a TOKEN_DEFAULT_DACL structure that contains the default DACL for newly created objects.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenSource
member.summary: The buffer receives a TOKEN_SOURCE structure that contains the source of the token. TOKEN_QUERY_SOURCE access is needed to retrieve this information.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenType
member.summary: The buffer receives a TOKEN_TYPE value that indicates whether the token is a primary or impersonation token.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenImpersonationLevel
member.summary: The buffer receives a SECURITY_IMPERSONATION_LEVEL value that indicates the impersonation level of the token. If the access token is not an impersonation token, the function fails.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenStatistics
member.summary: The buffer receives a TOKEN_STATISTICS structure that contains various token statistics.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenRestrictedSids
member.summary: The buffer receives a TOKEN_GROUPS structure that contains the list of restricting SIDs in a restricted token.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenSessionId
member.summary: The buffer receives a DWORD value that indicates the Terminal Services session identifier that is associated with the token.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenGroupsAndPrivileges
member.summary: The buffer receives a TOKEN_GROUPS_AND_PRIVILEGES structure that contains the user SID, the group accounts, the restricted SIDs, and the authentication ID associated with the token.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenSessionReference
member.summary: Reserved.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenSandBoxInert
member.summary: The buffer receives a DWORD value that is nonzero if the token includes the SANDBOX_INERT flag.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenAuditPolicy
member.summary: Reserved.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenOrigin
member.summary: The buffer receives a TOKEN_ORIGIN value.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenElevationType
member.summary: The buffer receives a TOKEN_ELEVATION_TYPE value that specifies the elevation level of the token.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenLinkedToken
member.summary: The buffer receives a TOKEN_LINKED_TOKEN structure that contains a handle to another token that is linked to this token.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenElevation
member.summary: The buffer receives a TOKEN_ELEVATION structure that specifies whether the token is elevated.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenHasRestrictions
member.summary: The buffer receives a DWORD value that is nonzero if the token has ever been filtered.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenAccessInformation
member.summary: The buffer receives a TOKEN_ACCESS_INFORMATION structure that specifies security information contained in the token.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenVirtualizationAllowed
member.summary: The buffer receives a DWORD value that is nonzero if virtualization is allowed for the token.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenVirtualizationEnabled
member.summary: The buffer receives a DWORD value that is nonzero if virtualization is enabled for the token.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenIntegrityLevel
member.summary: The buffer receives a TOKEN_MANDATORY_LABEL structure that specifies the token's integrity level.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenUIAccess
member.summary: The buffer receives a DWORD value that is nonzero if the token has the UIAccess flag set.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenMandatoryPolicy
member.summary: The buffer receives a TOKEN_MANDATORY_POLICY structure that specifies the token's mandatory integrity policy.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS.TokenLogonSid
member.summary: The buffer receives the token's logon security identifier (SID).

member.summary: The maximum value for this enumeration

member.name: T:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.ProcessAccessTypes
member.summary: Win32 ProcessAccessTypes enumeration.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.ProcessAccessTypes.PROCESS_TERMINATE
member.summary: Enables usage of the process handle in the TerminateProcess function to terminate the process.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.ProcessAccessTypes.PROCESS_CREATE_THREAD
member.summary: Enables usage of the process handle in the CreateRemoteThread function to create a thread in the process.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.ProcessAccessTypes.PROCESS_SET_SESSIONID
member.summary: Sets the session ID.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.ProcessAccessTypes.PROCESS_VM_OPERATION
member.summary: Enables usage of the process handle in the VirtualProtectEx and WriteProcessMemory functions to modify the virtual memory of the process.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.ProcessAccessTypes.PROCESS_VM_READ
member.summary: Enables usage of the process handle in the ReadProcessMemory function to read from the virtual memory of the process.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.ProcessAccessTypes.PROCESS_VM_WRITE
member.summary: Enables usage of the process handle in the WriteProcessMemory function to write to the virtual memory of the process.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.ProcessAccessTypes.PROCESS_DUP_HANDLE
member.summary: Enables usage of the process handle as either the source or target process in the DuplicateHandle function to duplicate a handle.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.ProcessAccessTypes.PROCESS_CREATE_PROCESS
member.summary: Creates a process.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.ProcessAccessTypes.PROCESS_SET_QUOTA
member.summary: Sets quota.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.ProcessAccessTypes.PROCESS_SET_INFORMATION
member.summary: Enables usage of the process handle in the SetPriorityClass function to set the priority class of the process.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.ProcessAccessTypes.PROCESS_QUERY_INFORMATION
member.summary: Enables usage of the process handle in the GetExitCodeProcess and GetPriorityClass functions to read information from the process object.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.ProcessAccessTypes.STANDARD_RIGHTS_REQUIRED
member.summary: Standard rights required.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.ProcessAccessTypes.SYNCHRONIZE
member.summary: Enables usage of the process handle in any of the wait functions to wait for the process to terminate.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.ProcessAccessTypes.PROCESS_ALL_ACCESS
member.summary: Specifies all possible access flags for the process object.

member.name: T:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.LogonFlags
member.summary: Win32 LogonFlags enumeration.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.LogonFlags.WithProfile
member.summary: Log on, then load the user's profile in the HKEY_USERS registry key. The function returns after the profile has been loaded. Loading the profile can be time-consuming, so it is best to use this value only if you must access the information in the HKEY_CURRENT_USER registry key. NOTE: Windows Server 2003: The profile is unloaded after the new process has been terminated, regardless of whether it has created child processes.
member.remarks: See LOGON_WITH_PROFILE

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.LogonFlags.NetCredentialsOnly
member.summary: Log on, but use the specified credentials on the network only. The new process uses the same token as the caller, but the system creates a new logon session within LSA, and the process uses the specified credentials as the default credentials. This value can be used to create a process that uses a different set of credentials locally than it does remotely. This is useful in inter-domain scenarios where there is no trust relationship. The system does not validate the specified credentials. Therefore, the process can start, but it may not have access to network resources.
member.remarks: See LOGON_NETCREDENTIALS_ONLY

member.name: T:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.PROCESS_INFORMATION
member.summary: Win32 PROCESS_INFORMATION structure.

member.name: T:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.STARTUPINFO
member.summary: Win32 STARTUPINFO structure.

member.name: T:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.SERVICE_DESCRIPTION
member.summary: Win32 SERVICE_DESCRIPTION structure.

remarks.para: A description of NULL indicates no service description exists. The service description is NULL when the service is created.

The description is simply a comment that explains the purpose of the service. For example, for the DHCP service, you could use the description "Provides internet addresses for computer on your network."

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.SERVICE_DESCRIPTION.lpDescription
member.summary: The description of the service.
member.remarks: If this member is NULL, the description remains unchanged. If this value is an empty string (""), the current description is deleted.

member.name: T:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.SC_ACTION
member.summary: Win32 SC_ACTION structure.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.SC_ACTION.Type
member.summary: The to be performed.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.SC_ACTION.Delay
member.summary: The time to wait before performing the specified action, in milliseconds.

member.name: T:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.SERVICE_FAILURE_ACTIONS
member.summary: Win32 SERVICE_FAILURE_ACTIONS structure.
member.remarks: Represents the action the service controller should take on each failure of a service. A service is considered failed when it terminates without reporting a status of SERVICE_STOPPED to the service controller.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.SERVICE_FAILURE_ACTIONS.dwResetPeriod
member.summary: The time after which to reset the failure count to zero if there are no failures, in seconds. Specify INFINITE to indicate that this value should never be reset.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.SERVICE_FAILURE_ACTIONS.lpRebootMsg
member.summary: The message to be broadcast to server users before rebooting in response to the SC_ACTION_REBOOT service controller action.
member.remarks: If this value is NULL, the reboot message is unchanged. If the value is an empty string (""), the reboot message is deleted and no message is broadcast.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.SERVICE_FAILURE_ACTIONS.lpCommand
member.summary: The command line of the process for the CreateProcess function to execute in response to the SC_ACTION_RUN_COMMAND service controller action. This process runs under the same account as the service.
member.remarks: If this value is NULL, the command is unchanged. If the value is an empty string (""), the command is deleted and no program is run when the service fails.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.SERVICE_FAILURE_ACTIONS.cActions
member.summary: The number of elements in the lpsaActions array.
member.remarks: If this value is 0, but lpsaActions is not NULL, the reset period and array of failure actions are deleted.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.SERVICE_FAILURE_ACTIONS.lpsaActions
member.summary: A pointer to an array of SC_ACTION structures.
member.remarks: If this value is NULL, the cActions and dwResetPeriod members are ignored.

member.name: T:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.SERVICE_FAILURE_ACTIONS_FLAG
member.summary: Win32 SERVICE_FAILURE_ACTIONS_FLAG structure.
member.remarks: Contains the failure actions flag setting of a service. This setting determines when failure actions are to be executed.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.SERVICE_FAILURE_ACTIONS_FLAG.bFailureAction
member.summary: If this member is TRUE and the service has configured failure actions, the failure actions are queued if the service process terminates without reporting a status of SERVICE_STOPPED or if it enters the SERVICE_STOPPED state but the dwWin32ExitCode member of the SERVICE_STATUS structure is not ERROR_SUCCESS (0). If this member is FALSE and the service has configured failure actions, the failure actions are queued only if the service terminates without reporting a status of SERVICE_STOPPED.

member.name: T:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.LUID_AND_ATTRIBUTES
member.summary: Win32 LUID_AND_ATTRIBUTES structure.
member.remarks: An LUID_AND_ATTRIBUTES structure can represent an LUID whose attributes change frequently, such as when the LUID is used to represent privileges in the PRIVILEGE_SET structure. Privileges are represented by LUIDs and have attributes indicating whether they are currently enabled or disabled.

member.summary: Specifies an LUID value.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.LUID_AND_ATTRIBUTES.Attributes
member.summary: Specifies attributes of the LUID. This value contains up to 32 one-bit flags. Its meaning is dependent on the definition and use of the LUID.

member.name: F:GSF.Interop.WindowsApi.TOKEN_PRIVILEGES.Privileges

member.name: T:GSF.IO.CachedFileStream
member.summary: Represents a file stream that caches recently used blocks in memory.

remarks.para: This class was developed as a wrapper around with the same basic functionality. This stream treats the file as a collection of contiguous blocks which can be loaded into an in-memory lookup table to greatly improve seek times. This class generally performs significantly better than the standard FileStream class when maintaining multiple file pointers and frequently seeking back and forth between them. For an example of a good use-case, consider copying a list of serialized objects from one location in the file to another without loading the whole list into memory.

This class likely will not perform significantly better or worse than the standard FileStream when performing strictly sequential reads or writes. For an example of a bad use-case, consider reading a list of objects into memory or simply appending new data to the end of the file. In both of these cases, it may be better to use the standard FileStream for less memory overhead and more predictable flush behavior.

Blocks are loaded into memory as they are used (for read/write operations) and will be kept in memory for as long as possible. Blocks can only be flushed from the cache by decreasing the cache size or by accessing a non-cached block when the cache is already full. In these cases, a least recently used algorithm is executed to determine which blocks should be removed from the cache either to decrease the size of the cache or to make room for a new block.

Write operations are also cached such that they will not be committed to the file until the block is removed from the cache or a call to has been made. This can have some additional implications as compared to the standard FileStream. For instance, write operations may not be committed to the file in the order in which they were executed. Users of this class will need to be judicious about when and how often they call Flush.

Specifies whether to use asynchronous I/O or synchronous I/O. However, note that the underlying operating system might not support asynchronous I/O, so when specifying true, the handle might be opened synchronously depending on the platform. When opened asynchronously, the and methods perform better on large reads or writes, but they might be much slower for small reads or writes. If the application is designed to take advantage of asynchronous I/O, set the parameter to true. Using asynchronous I/O correctly can speed up applications by as much as a factor of 10, but using it without redesigning the application for asynchronous I/O can decrease performance by as much as a factor of 10.

member.name: M:GSF.IO.FilePath.GetUniqueFilePath(System.String)
member.summary: Gets a unique file path for the given file by checking for name collisions and adding a sequence number to the end of the file name if there is a collision.
member.param: The path to the original file before adding the sequence number.
member.returns: The unique path to the file.
member.remarks:
This method is designed to handle the case where the user wishes to create a file in a folder with a given name when there is a possibility that the name is already taken. Using this method, it is possible to create files with names in the following format:
File.ext
File (1).ext
File (2).ext
...
This method uses a linear search to find a unique file name, so it is suitable for situations where there are a small number of collisions for each file name. This will detect and fill gaps that can occur when files are deleted (for instance, if "File (1).ext" were deleted from the list above).

member.name: M:GSF.IO.FilePath.GetUniqueFilePathWithBinarySearch(System.String)
member.summary: Gets a unique file path for the given file by checking for name collisions and adding a sequence number to the end of the file name if there is a collision.
member.param: The path to the original file before adding the sequence number.
member.returns: The unique path to the file.
member.remarks:
This method is designed to handle the case where the user wishes to create a file in a folder with a given name when there is a possibility that the name is already taken. Using this method, it is possible to create files with names in the following format:
File.ext
File (1).ext
File (2).ext
...
This method uses a binary search to find a unique file name, so it is suitable for situations where a large number of files will be created with the same file name, and the next unique file name needs to be found relatively quickly. It will not always detect gaps in the sequence numbers that can occur when files are deleted (for instance, if "File (1).ext" were deleted from the list above).

member.name: M:GSF.IO.FilePath.ValidatePathName(System.String)

member.name: M:GSF.IO.FilePath.IsFilePatternMatch(System.String[],System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Determines whether the specified file name matches any of the given file specs (wildcards are defined as '*' or '?' characters).
member.param: The file specs used for matching the specified file name.
The file path to be tested against the specified file specs for a match.
true to specify a case-insensitive match; otherwise false.
member.returns: true if the specified file name matches any of the given file specs; otherwise false.
member.exception: contains one or more of the invalid characters defined in .
member.remarks:
The syntax for adheres to the following rules:
Either '\' or '/' (as defined by and ) can match the other.
A single '\' or '/' at the beginning of the pattern matches any valid path root (such as "C:\" or "\\server\share").
A '?' matches a single character which would be valid in a file name (as defined by ).
A '*' matches any number of characters which would be valid in a file name.
A sequence of "**\" or "**/" matches any number of sequential directories.
Any other character matches itself.

member.name: T:GSF.IO.OutageLog
member.summary: Represents a persisted log of outages as a list of start and stop times.

remarks.para: This class serializes a list of outages (e.g., a connection outage or data loss) where each outage consists of a start and end time. The outages are persisted in a log file so that the log can be operated on even through host application restarts until the outages are processed.
All members in the are guaranteed to be thread safe. File locks are used to provide synchronization so that the file can stay up-to-date with changes made in the application.

member.name: M:GSF.IO.RunTimeLog.Initialize
member.summary: Initialize the run-time log.

remarks.para: Initialization performs initial run-time log read, establishes new start time and enables automatic write log timer.

Last logged stop time will be validated against last logged running time. If the last logged running time is later than the last logged stop time, the stop time will be set to the running time with the assumption that the log file was not properly shut down (e.g., due to abnormal host termination).
It is important to separate initialization from construction such that consumer can attach to events before class is initialized in case initialization causes events to be raised.

member.name: T:GSF.IO.SafeFileWatcher
member.summary: Represents a wrapper around the native .NET that avoids problems with dangling references when using a file watcher instance as a class member that never gets disposed.

remarks.para: The design goal of the SafeFileWatcher is to avoid accidental memory leaks caused by use of .NET's native file system watcher when used as a member of a class that consumers fail to properly dispose. If a class has a reference to a file watcher as a member variable and attaches to the file watcher's events, the file watcher will maintain a reference the parent class so it can call its event handler. If the parent class is not disposed properly, the file watcher will thusly not be disposed and will maintain the reference to the parent class - the garbage collector will never collect the parent because it has a valid reference and no collection means the parent finalizer will never get called and the file system watcher will never get disposed. Creating multiple instances of parent class and not disposing of them will cause a memory leak even with a properly designed disposable pattern. Using the SafeFileWatcher instead of directly using the FileSystemWatcher will resolve this potential issue.

Note that component model implementation is not fully replicated - if you are using a file system watcher on a design surface, this safety wrapper will usually not be needed. This class has benefit when a class will dynamically use a file watcher and needs to make sure any unmanaged resources get properly released even if a consumer neglects to call the dispose function.

member.name: M:GSF.IO.Compression.PatternCompressor.CompressBuffer(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Byte)
member.summary: Compress a byte array containing a sequential list of 32-bit structures (e.g., floating point numbers, integers or unsigned integers) using a patterned compression method.
member.param: The array containing 32-bit values to compress. Compression will happen inline on this buffer.
An representing the start index of the byte array.
The number of bytes in the buffer that represents actual data.

The number of bytes available for use in the buffer; actual buffer length must be at least one byte larger than since it's possible that data cannot be compressed. This extra byte will be used indicate an uncompressed buffer.
Specifies compression strength (0 to 31). Smaller numbers will run faster, larger numbers will yield better compression.
member.returns: The new length of the buffer after compression.
member.exception: buffer cannot be null.
must be greater than or equal to zero.
must be an even multiple of 4.
must be at least one byte larger than in case data cannot be compressed.
Actual length of buffer is less than specified .
must be 0 to 31.
member.remarks: As an optimization this function is using pointers to native structures, as such the endian order decoding and encoding of the values will always be in the native endian order of the operating system.

member.name: M:GSF.IO.Compression.PatternDecompressor.Reset
member.summary: Resets the decompressor by flushing the back buffer. Subsequent calls to the Decompress methods will not be decompressed using previously decompressed values.

member.name: M:GSF.IO.Compression.PatternDecompressor.EmptyBuffer
member.summary: Clears out the data buffer so that subsequent calls to the Decompress methods do not use the data that was previously in the data buffer.
member.remarks: This method should not be called during normal operation, as data will be lost and the compressed stream will likely be corrupted. Only call this method if the stream has already been corrupted.

member.name: M:GSF.IO.Compression.PatternDecompressor.MaximumSizeDecompressed(System.Int32)
member.summary: Given the size of a compressed buffer, provides the maximum possible size of the decompressed data.
member.param: Size of the compressed buffer.
member.returns: The maximum possible size of the data after decompression.

member.name: M:GSF.IO.Compression.PatternDecompressor.DecompressBuffer(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Decompress a byte array containing a sequential list of compressed 32-bit structures (e.g., floating point numbers, integers or unsigned integers) using a patterned compression method.
member.param: The array containing compressed 32-bit values to be decompressed. Decompression will happen inline on this buffer.
An representing the start index of the byte array.
The number of bytes in the buffer that represents actual data.
The number of bytes available for use in the buffer; actual buffer length must be at least large enough to fit the maximum size of the decompressed data. See .
member.returns: The new length of the buffer after compression, unless the data cannot be compressed. If the data cannot be compressed, the buffer will remain unchanged and zero will be returned.
member.exception: buffer cannot be null.
must be greater than or equal to one.
must be at least as large as .
must be at least as large as is necessary to fit the maximum possible size of the decompressed data.
Actual length of buffer is less than specified .

remarks.para: Decompression is performed inline. The source buffer must be large enough to contain the maximum possible size of the decompressed buffer. This maximum size can be obtained by using the method.

As an optimization this function is using pointers to native structures, as such the endian order decoding and encoding of the values will always be in the native endian order of the operating system.

member.name: T:GSF.IO.InterprocessCache
member.summary: Represents a serialized data cache that can be saved or read from multiple applications using inter-process synchronization.
member.remarks: Note that all file data in this class gets serialized to and from memory, as such, the design intention for this class is for use with smaller data sets such as serialized lists or dictionaries that need inter-process synchronized loading and saving.

member.name: P:GSF.IO.InterprocessCache.ReloadOnChange
member.summary: Gets or sets flag that enables system to monitor for changes in and automatically reload .
member.remarks: Use extreme caution when enabling this property - it will be critical to dispose of this class when this property is set to true since it will create a file watcher that attaches to an event referenced by this class using pinned memory, as a result, this class will not get garbage collected until this class is disposed thus detaching the associated event.

member.name: T:GSF.IO.IsamDataFileBase`1
member.summary: An abstract class that defines the read/write capabilities for ISAM (Indexed Sequential Access Method) file.
member.typeparam: of the records the file contains. This must implement the interface.

remarks.para: This ISAM implementation keeps all the records in memory, so it may not be suitable for very large files. Since data is stored in memory using a list, the maximum number of possible supported records will be 2,147,483,647 (i.e., Int32.MaxValue).
See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISAM for more information on ISAM files.

member.name: T:GSF.IO.NamespaceDoc

member.name: T:GSF.IO.BlockAllocatedMemoryStream
member.summary: Defines a stream whose backing store is memory. Externally this class operates similar to a , internally it uses dynamically allocated buffer blocks instead of one large contiguous array of data.

remarks.para: The has two primary benefits over a normal , first, the allocation of a large contiguous array of data in can fail when the requested amount of contiguous memory is unavailable - the prevents this; second, a will constantly reallocate the buffer size as the stream grows and shrinks and then copy all the data from the old buffer to the new - the maintains its blocks over its life cycle, unless manually cleared, thus eliminating unnecessary allocations and garbage collections when growing and reusing a stream.

Important: Unlike , the will not use a user provided buffer as its backing buffer. Any user provided buffers used to instantiate the class will be copied into internally managed reusable memory buffers. Subsequently, the does not support the notion of a non-expandable stream. If you are using a with your own buffer, the will not provide any immediate benefit.
Note that the will maintain all allocated blocks for stream use until the method is called or the class is disposed.
No members in the are guaranteed to be thread safe. Make sure any calls are synchronized when simultaneously accessed from different threads.

member.name: M:GSF.BitExtensions.BitRotL(System.Byte,System.Int32)
member.summary: Performs rightwise bit-rotation for the specified number of rotations.
member.param: Value used for bit-rotation.
Number of rotations to perform.
member.returns: Value that has its bits rotated to the right the specified number of times.
member.remarks: Actual rotation direction is from a big-endian perspective - this is an artifact of the native .NET bit shift operators. As a result bits may actually appear to rotate right on little-endian architectures.
