member.name: T:GSF.BitwiseCast
member.summary: Defines specialized bitwise integer data type conversion functions
member.remarks: This class allows for proper bitwise casting between signed and unsigned integers. It may be most useful in languages that do not allow override of numerical overflow checks. For example, C# provides an "unchecked" keyword to allow for bitwise casting, but VB.NET does not.

member.name: M:GSF.BitwiseCast.ToInt16(System.UInt16)
member.summary: Performs proper bitwise conversion between unsigned and signed value

remarks.para: This function is useful because Convert.ToInt16 will throw an OverflowException for values greater than Int16.MaxValue.
For example, this function correctly converts unsigned 16-bit integer 65535 (i.e., UInt16.MaxValue) to signed 16-bit integer -1.

member.param: Unsigned short that is passed in to be converted to a signed short.
member.returns: The converted short value.

member.name: M:GSF.BitwiseCast.ToInt24(GSF.UInt24)
member.summary: Performs proper bitwise conversion between unsigned and signed value

remarks.para: This function is useful because CType(n, Int24) will throw an OverflowException for values greater than Int24.MaxValue.
For example, this function correctly converts unsigned 24-bit integer 16777215 (i.e., UInt24.MaxValue) to signed 24-bit integer -1.

member.param: Unsigned UInt24 that is passed in to be converted to a signed Int24.
member.returns: The Int24 value.

member.name: M:GSF.BitwiseCast.ToInt32(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Performs proper bitwise conversion between unsigned and signed value

remarks.para: This function is useful because Convert.ToInt32 will throw an OverflowException for values greater than Int32.MaxValue.
For example, this function correctly converts unsigned 32-bit integer 4294967295 (i.e., UInt32.MaxValue) to signed 32-bit integer -1.

member.param: Unsigned integer that is passed in to be converted to a signed Int32.
member.returns: The int value.

member.name: M:GSF.BitwiseCast.ToInt64(System.UInt64)
member.summary: Performs proper bitwise conversion between unsigned and signed value

remarks.para: This function is useful because Convert.ToInt64 will throw an OverflowException for values greater than Int64.MaxValue.
For example, this function correctly converts unsigned 64-bit integer 18446744073709551615 (i.e., UInt64.MaxValue) to signed 64-bit integer -1.

member.param: Unsigned integer that is passed in to be converted to a long.
member.returns: The long value.

member.name: M:GSF.BitwiseCast.ToUInt16(System.Int16)
member.summary: Performs proper bitwise conversion between signed and unsigned value

remarks.para: This function is useful because Convert.ToUInt16 will throw an OverflowException for values less than zero.
For example, this function correctly converts signed 16-bit integer -32768 (i.e., Int16.MinValue) to unsigned 16-bit integer 32768.

member.param: Signed integer that is passed in to be converted to an unsigned short.
member.returns: The unsigned short value.

member.name: M:GSF.BitwiseCast.ToUInt24(GSF.Int24)
member.summary: Performs proper bitwise conversion between signed and unsigned value

remarks.para: This function is useful because CType(n, UInt24) will throw an OverflowException for values less than zero.
For example, this function correctly converts signed 24-bit integer -8388608 (i.e., Int24.MinValue) to unsigned 24-bit integer 8388608.

member.param: Signed integer that is passed in to be converted to an unsigned integer.
member.returns: The unsigned integer value.

member.name: M:GSF.BitwiseCast.ToUInt32(System.Int32)
member.summary: Performs proper bitwise conversion between signed and unsigned value

remarks.para: This function is useful because Convert.ToUInt32 will throw an OverflowException for values less than zero.
For example, this function correctly converts signed 32-bit integer -2147483648 (i.e., Int32.MinValue) to unsigned 32-bit integer 2147483648.

member.param: Signed integer that is passed in to be converted to an unsigned integer.
member.returns: The unsigned integer value.

member.name: M:GSF.BitwiseCast.ToUInt64(System.Int64)
member.summary: Performs proper bitwise conversion between signed and unsigned value

remarks.para: This function is useful because Convert.ToUInt64 will throw an OverflowException for values less than zero.
For example, this function correctly converts signed 64-bit integer -9223372036854775808 (i.e., Int64.MinValue) to unsigned 64-bit integer 9223372036854775808.

member.param: Signed integer that is passed in to be converted to an unsigned long.
member.returns: The unsigned long value.

member.name: P:GSF.ByteEncoding.Hexadecimal
member.summary: Handles encoding and decoding of a byte buffer into a hexadecimal-based presentation format.

member.name: P:GSF.ByteEncoding.Decimal
member.summary: Handles encoding and decoding of a byte buffer into an integer-based presentation format.

member.name: P:GSF.ByteEncoding.BigEndianBinary
member.summary: Handles encoding and decoding of a byte buffer into a big-endian binary (i.e., 0 and 1's) based presentation format.
member.remarks: Although endianness is typically used in the context of byte order (see to handle byte order swapping), this property allows you visualize "bits" in big-endian order, right-to-left. Note that bits are normally stored in the same order as their bytes.).

member.name: P:GSF.ByteEncoding.LittleEndianBinary
member.summary: Handles encoding and decoding of a byte buffer into a little-endian binary (i.e., 0 and 1's) based presentation format.
member.remarks: Although endianness is typically used in the context of byte order (see to handle byte order swapping), this property allows you visualize "bits" in little-endian order, left-to-right. Note that bits are normally stored in the same order as their bytes.

member.name: P:GSF.ByteEncoding.Base64
member.summary: Handles encoding and decoding of a byte buffer into a base64 presentation format.

member.name: P:GSF.ByteEncoding.ASCII
member.summary: Handles encoding and decoding of a byte buffer into an ASCII character presentation format.

member.name: T:GSF.CompoundValue`1
member.summary: Represents a collection of individual values that together represent a compound value once all the values have been assigned.
member.remarks: Composite values are stored as and can be cumulated until all values have been assigned so that a compound value can be created.
member.typeparam: of composite values.

member.summary: Creates a new .

member.name: M:GSF.CompoundValue`1.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a new specifing the total number of composite values to track.
member.remarks: The specified of items are added to the , each item will be marked as unassigned (i.e., null).
member.param: Total number of composite values to track.

member.name: M:GSF.CompoundValue`1.#ctor(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{`0})
member.summary: Creates a new from the specified list.

member.summary: Creates a new from the specified list.
member.param: List of values used to initialize .

member.name: P:GSF.CompoundValue`1.AllAssigned
member.summary: Gets a boolean value indicating if all of the composite values have been assigned a value.
member.returns: True, if all composite values have been assigned a value; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:GSF.CompoundValue`1.NoneAssigned
member.summary: Gets a boolean value indicating if none of the composite values have been assigned a value.
member.returns: True, if no composite values have been assigned a value; otherwise, false.

member.summary: Gets an array of all the elements of the .
member.returns: A new array containing copies of the elements of the .

member.name: T:GSF.Configuration.AppSettingsBase
member.summary: Represents the base class for application settings that are synchronized with the "appSettings" section in a configuration file.

remarks.para:
In order to make custom types serializable for the configuration file, implement a for the type.
See MSDN for details.

member.name: M:GSF.Configuration.CategorizedSettingsBase.#ctor(System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class for the application's configuration file.
member.param: Name of default category to use to get and set settings from configuration file.
Determines if category attributes will be used for category names.
Assigns flag that determines if is required to exist before a field or property is serialized to the configuration file.
member.remarks: If is false, all settings will be placed in section labeled by the value; otherwise, if a exists on a field or property then the member value will serialized into the configuration file in a section labeled the same as the value and if the attribute doesn't exist the member value will serialized into the section labeled by the value.

member.name: P:GSF.Configuration.CategorizedSettingsElement.Value
member.summary: Gets or sets the value of the setting.
member.returns: The value of the setting.
member.remarks:
can reference the value of another setting using Eval([Section].[Setting]) syntax or the value of a known .NET type's static member (field, non-indexed property or parameterless method) using Eval([Type].[Member]) syntax as shown in the example below:
<?xml version="1.0"?> <configuration> <configSections> <section name="categorizedSettings" type="GSF.Configuration.CategorizedSettingsSection, GSF.Core" /> </configSections> <categorizedSettings> <database> <add name="SettingsTable" value="dbo.Settings" description="Table that contains the settings." encrypted="false" /> <add name="AdminEmail" value="SELECT * FROM Eval(Database.SettingsTable) WHERE Name = 'AdminEmail'" description="Email address of the administrator." encrypted="false" /> <add name="AuditQuery" value="SELECT * FROM dbo.Log WHERE EntryTime < 'Eval(System.DateTime.UtcNow)'" description="Query for retrieving audit records." encrypted="false" /> </database> </categorizedSettings> </configuration>

Determines if category attributes will be used for section names.
Assigns flag that determines if is required to exist before a field or property is serialized to the INI file.
member.remarks: If is false, all settings will be placed in section labeled by the value; otherwise, if a exists on a field or property then the member value will serialized into the INI file in a section labeled the same as the value and if the attribute doesn't exist the member value will serialized into the section labeled by the value.

Name of default section to use to get and set settings from INI file.
Determines if category attributes will be used for section names.
Assigns flag that determines if is required to exist before a field or property is serialized to the INI file.
Determines if method should be called from constructor.

remarks.para: If is false, all settings will be placed in section labeled by the value; otherwise, if a exists on a field or property then the member value will serialized into the INI file in a section labeled the same as the value and if the attribute doesn't exist the member value will serialized into the section labeled by the value.

Note that some .NET languages (e.g., Visual Basic) will not initialize member elements before call to constuctor, in this case should be set to false, then the method should be called manually after all properties have been initialized. Alternately, consider using the on the fields or properties and this will be used to initialize the values.

member.name: T:GSF.DateTimeExtensions
member.summary: Defines extension functions related to Date/Time manipulation.

member.name: M:GSF.DateTimeExtensions.UtcTimeIsValid(System.DateTime,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Determines if the specified UTC time is valid, by comparing it to the system clock.
member.param: UTC time to test for validity.
The allowed lag time, in seconds, before assuming time is too old to be valid.
The allowed lead time, in seconds, before assuming time is too advanced to be valid.
member.returns: True, if time is within the specified range.

remarks.para: Time is considered valid if it exists within the specified lag time/lead time range of current time.
Note that lag time and lead time must be greater than zero, but can be set to sub-second intervals.

member.exception: LagTime and LeadTime must be greater than zero, but can be less than one.

member.name: M:GSF.DateTimeExtensions.LocalTimeIsValid(System.DateTime,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Determines if the specified local time is valid, by comparing it to the system clock.
member.param: Time to test for validity.
The allowed lag time, in seconds, before assuming time is too old to be valid.
The allowed lead time, in seconds, before assuming time is too advanced to be valid.
member.returns: True, if time is within the specified range.

remarks.para: Time is considered valid if it exists within the specified lag time/lead time range of current time.
Note that lag time and lead time must be greater than zero, but can be set to sub-second intervals.

member.exception: LagTime and LeadTime must be greater than zero, but can be less than one.

member.name: M:GSF.DateTimeExtensions.TimeIsValid(System.DateTime,System.DateTime,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Determines if time is valid, by comparing it to the specified current time.
member.param: Time to test for validity.
Specified current time (e.g., could be Date.Now or Date.UtcNow).
The allowed lag time, in seconds, before assuming time is too old to be valid.
The allowed lead time, in seconds, before assuming time is too advanced to be valid.
member.returns: True, if time is within the specified range.

remarks.para: Time is considered valid if it exists within the specified lag time/lead time range of current time.
Note that lag time and lead time must be greater than zero, but can be set to sub-second intervals.

member.exception: LagTime and LeadTime must be greater than zero, but can be less than one.

member.summary: Gets the distance, in , beyond the top of the second.

member.returns: Timestamp's tick distance from the top of the second.

member.name: M:GSF.DateTimeExtensions.BaselinedTimestamp(System.DateTime,GSF.BaselineTimeInterval)
member.summary: Creates a baselined timestamp which begins at the specified time interval.
member.param: Timestamp to baseline.
to which should be baselined.
member.returns: A new value that represents a baselined timestamp that begins at the specified .
member.remarks:
Baselining to the would return the value starting at zero milliseconds.
Baselining to the would return the value starting at zero seconds and milliseconds.
Baselining to the would return the value starting at zero minutes, seconds and milliseconds.
Baselining to the would return the value starting at zero hours, minutes, seconds and milliseconds.
Baselining to the would return the value starting at day one, zero hours, minutes, seconds and milliseconds.
Baselining to the would return the value starting at month one, day one, zero hours, minutes, seconds and milliseconds.

member.name: T:GSF.EndianOrder
member.summary: Represents an endian byte order interoperability class.
member.remarks: Intel systems use little-endian byte order, other systems, such as Unix, use big-endian byte ordering. Little-endian ordering means bits are ordered such that the bit whose in-memory representation is right-most is the most-significant-bit in a byte. Big-endian ordering means bits are ordered such that the bit whose in-memory representation is left-most is the most-significant-bit in a byte.

member.name: T:GSF.ErrorManagement.ErrorLogger
member.summary: Represents a logger that can be used for logging handled as well as unhandled exceptions across multiple application types (Console Application, Windows Service, Web Application, Web Service).

remarks.para: Adapted from exception handling code by Jeff Atwood of CodingHorror.com. Demo projects for handling unhandled exception in both windows and web environment by Jeff Atwood are available at The Code Project web site. See: http://www.codeproject.com/script/articles/list_articles.asp?userid=450027
Error logger with Windows Forms capabilities can be found in the GSF.Windows assembly.

member.name: T:GSF.ErrorManagement.ErrorModule
member.summary: Represents an HTTP module that can be used to handle exceptions globally in Web Sites and Web Services.
member.example:
Below is the config file entry required for enabling error handling using :
<configuration> <system.web> <httpModules> <add name="ErrorModule" type="GSF.ErrorManagement.ErrorModule, GSF.Core" /> </httpModules> </system.web> </configuration>
Below is the config file entry required for changing the settings of :
<configuration> <configSections> <section name="categorizedSettings" type="GSF.Configuration.CategorizedSettingsSection, GSF.Core" /> </configSections> <categorizedSettings> <errorLogger> <add name="LogToUI" value="False" description="True if an encountered exception is to be logged to the User Interface; otherwise False." encrypted="false" /> <add name="LogToFile" value="True" description="True if an encountered exception is to be logged to a file; otherwise False." encrypted="false" /> <add name="LogToEmail" value="False" description="True if an email is to be sent to ContactEmail with the details of an encountered exception; otherwise False." encrypted="false" /> <add name="LogToEventLog" value="True" description="True if an encountered exception is to be logged to the Event Log; otherwise False." encrypted="false" /> <add name="LogToScreenshot" value="False" description="True if a screenshot is to be taken when an exception is encountered; otherwise False." encrypted="false" /> <add name="SmtpServer" value="smtp.email.com" description="Name of the SMTP server to be used for sending the email messages." encrypted="false" /> <add name="ContactEmail" value="" description="Comma-seperated list of recipient email addresses for the email message." encrypted="false" /> <add name="ContactName" value="" description="Name of the person that the end-user can contact when an exception is encountered." encrypted="false" /> <add name="ContactPhone" value="" description="Phone number of the person that the end-user can contact when an exception is encountered." encrypted="false" /> <add name="HandleUnhandledException" value="True" description="True if unhandled exceptions are to be handled automatically; otherwise False." encrypted="false" /> <add name="ExitOnUnhandledException" value="False" description="True if the application must exit when an unhandled exception is encountered; otherwise False." encrypted="false" /> </errorLogger> </categorizedSettings> </configuration>

member.summary: Initializes the and prepares it to handle requests.
member.param: The to use for initialization.

member.summary: Disposes the resources (other than memory) used by the .

member.name: T:GSF.ErrorManagement.SmtpTraceListener
member.summary: Represents an e-mail based .
member.example:
Below is the config file entry required for enabling e-mail based tracing using :
<configuration> <system.diagnostics> <trace> <listeners> <add name="SmtpTraceListener" type="GSF.ErrorManagement.SmtpTraceListener,GSF.Core" initializeData="sender@email.com,recipient@email.com,smtp.email.com"/> </listeners> </trace> </system.diagnostics> </configuration>

member.name: T:GSF.BufferPool
member.summary: Represents a common buffer pool that can be used by an application.

remarks.para: The buffer pool is statically created at application startup and is available for all components and classes within an application domain. Every time you need to use a buffer, you take one from the pool, use it, and return it to the pool when done.

It is very important to return the buffer to the pool when you are finished using it. If you are using a buffer scoped within a method, make sure to use a try/finally so that you can take the buffer within the try and return the buffer within the finally. If you are using a buffer as a member scoped class field, make sure you use the standard dispose pattern and return the buffer in the method.
Internally this class simply wraps a static instance of the WCF .

member.name: M:GSF.BufferPool.TakeBuffer(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets a buffer of at least the specified size from the pool.
member.param: The size, in bytes, of the requested buffer.
member.returns: A byte array that is the requested size of the buffer.
member.exception: cannot be less than zero.

member.name: M:GSF.BufferPool.ReturnBuffer(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Returns a buffer to the pool.
member.param: A reference to the buffer being returned.
member.exception: reference cannot be null.
Length of does not match the pool's buffer length property.

member.name: M:GSF.BufferPool.Clear
member.summary: Releases all the buffers currently cached in the pool.

member.summary: Specifies that this object provides support for performing tasks during the key stages of object lifecycle.

member.name: E:GSF.ISupportLifecycle.Disposed
member.summary: Raised after the source object has been properly disposed.

member.name: M:GSF.ISupportLifecycle.Initialize
member.summary: Initializes the state of the object.

remarks.para: Typical implementation of should allow the object state to be initialized only once. should be called automatically from one or more key entry points of the object. For example, if the object is a and it implements the interface then should be called from the method so that the object gets initialized automatically when consumed through the IDE designer surface. In addition to this should also be called from key or mandatory methods of the object, like 'Start()' or 'Connect()', so that the object gets initialized even when not consumed through the IDE designer surface.

member.name: P:GSF.ISupportLifecycle.Enabled
member.summary: Gets or sets a boolean value that indicates whether the object is enabled.

member.name: M:GSF.NumericalAnalysis.Euclidean.Wrap(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Wraps a value to a range of values defined by the given minimum value and range.
member.param: The value to be wrapped.
The minimum value of the range.
The size of the range.
member.returns: The given value wrapped to the given range.
member.remarks: This method wraps the given value based on the assumption that for every pair of values x and y where x-y=range, the values are equivalent. This is probably most widely understood in terms of angles, where 0, 360, 720, etc. are all equivalent angles. If you wanted to wrap an angle such that it is between 120 and 480, for instance, you could call Euclidean.Wrap(angle, 120, 360).

member.summary: This class will contain various optimizations that can be enabled in certain circumstances through the SystemSettings. Since this framework is used in many settings, for stability reasons, tradeoffs are made. This gives the users opportunities to enable/disable certain optimizations if for some reason they cause adverse effects on their system.

member.name: M:GSF.Parsing.BinaryImageParserBase.ParseFrame(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Protocol specific frame parsing algorithm.
member.param: Buffer containing data to parse.
Offset index into buffer that represents where to start parsing.
Maximum length of valid data from offset.
member.returns: The length of the data that was parsed.

remarks.para: Implementers can choose to focus on parsing a single frame in the buffer even if there are other frames available in the buffer. Base class will continue to move through buffer on behalf of derived class until all the buffer has been processed. Just return the total amount of data was parsed and the remaining unparsed will be prepended to next received buffer.

Derived implementations should return an integer value that represents the length of the data that was parsed, and zero if not enough data was able to be parsed. Note that exceptions are expensive when parsing fast moving streaming data and a good coding practice for implementations of this method will be to not throw an exception when there is not enough data to parse the data, instead check the property to verify there is enough buffer data to represent the desired image. If there is not enough data to represent the image return zero and base class will prepend buffer onto next incoming set of data.

Because of the expense incurred when an exception is thrown, any exceptions encountered in the derived implementations of this method will cause the current data buffer to be discarded and a event to be raised. Doing this prevents exceptions from being thrown repeatedly for the same data. If your code implementation recognizes a malformed image, you can raise a custom event to indicate this instead of throwing as exception and keep moving through the buffer as an optimization.

member.name: T:GSF.Parsing.FrameImageParserBase`2
member.summary: This class defines a basic implementation of parsing functionality suitable for automating the parsing of a binary data stream represented as frames with common headers and returning the parsed data via an event.

remarks.para: This parser is designed as a write-only stream such that data can come from any source.

This class is more specific than the in that it can automate the parsing of a particular protocol that is formatted as a series of frames that have a common method of identification. Automation of type creation occurs by loading implementations of common types that implement the interface. The common method of identification is handled by creating a class derived from the which primarily includes a TypeID property, but also should include any state information needed to parse a particular frame if necessary. Derived classes simply override the function in order to parse the from a provided binary image.

member.name: M:GSF.Parsing.FrameImageParserBase`2.ParseCommonHeader(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Parses a common header instance that implements for the output type represented in the binary image.
member.param: Buffer containing data to parse.
Offset index into buffer that represents where to start parsing.
Maximum length of valid data from offset.
member.returns: The which includes a type ID for the to be parsed.

remarks.para: Derived classes need to provide a common header instance (i.e., class that implements ) for the output types; this will primarily include an ID of the that the data image represents. This parsing is only for common header information, actual parsing will be handled by output type via its method. This header image should also be used to add needed complex state information about the output type being parsed if needed.

If there is not enough buffer available to parse common header (as determined by ), return null. Also, if the protocol allows frame length to be determined at the time common header is being parsed and there is not enough buffer to parse the entire frame, it will be optimal to prevent further parsing by returning null.

member.name: T:GSF.Parsing.MultiSourceFrameImageParserBase`3
member.summary: This class defines a basic implementation of parsing functionality suitable for automating the parsing of multiple binary data streams, each represented as frames with common headers and returning the parsed data via an event.

remarks.para: This parser is designed as a write-only stream such that data can come from any source.

This class is more specific than the in that it can automate the parsing of a particular protocol that is formatted as a series of frames that have a common method of identification. Automation of type creation occurs by loading implementations of common types that implement the interface. The common method of identification is handled by creating a class derived from the which primarily includes a TypeID property, but also should include any state information needed to parse a particular frame if necessary. Derived classes override the method in order to parse the from a provided binary image.

member.typeparam: Type of identifier for the data source.

member.name: T:GSF.Parsing.TemplatedExpressionParser
member.summary: Represents a template based token substitution parser that supports binary and advanced expressions.

remarks.para:
Parser also supports more complex C# style expressions using the "eval{}" function, e.g.:
eval{'{CompanyAcronym}'.Substring(0,3)}_{DeviceAcronym}eval{'[?{SignalType.Source}=Phasor[-{SignalType.Suffix}]]'.Length}

member.name: M:GSF.Parsing.TemplatedExpressionParser.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new .

member.name: M:GSF.Parsing.TemplatedExpressionParser.#ctor(System.Char,System.Char,System.Char,System.Char)
member.summary: Creates a new with desired delimiters.
member.param: Character that identifies the beginning of a token.
Character that identifies the end of a token.
Character that identifies the beginning of an expression.
Character that identifies the beginning of an expression.

member.name: P:GSF.Parsing.TemplatedExpressionParser.TemplatedExpression
member.summary: Gets or sets the templated expression to use.

member.name: P:GSF.Parsing.TemplatedExpressionParser.ReservedSymbols
member.summary: Gets the reserved symbols - this includes all delimiters and expression operators.
member.remarks: The default reserved symbol list is: \, <, >, =, !, {, }, [ and ]

member.name: P:GSF.Parsing.TemplatedExpressionParser.StartTokenDelimiter
member.summary: Gets the character that identifies the beginning of a token.

member.name: P:GSF.Parsing.TemplatedExpressionParser.EndTokenDelimiter
member.summary: Gets the character that identifies the end of a token.

member.name: P:GSF.Parsing.TemplatedExpressionParser.StartExpressionDelimiter
member.summary: Gets the character that identifies the start of an expression.

member.name: P:GSF.Parsing.TemplatedExpressionParser.EndExpressionDelimiter
member.summary: Gets the character that identifies the end of an expression.

member.name: M:GSF.Parsing.TemplatedExpressionParser.Execute(System.Collections.Generic.IDictionary{System.String,System.String},System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Executes replacements using provided dictionary on the currently defined value and optionally evaluates any expressions.
member.param: Dictionary of substitutions. Dictionary keys are tokens to be replaced by the values.
Determines if substitutions should be case insensitive. Defaults to true.
Determines if expressions should be evaluated. Defaults to true.
member.returns: A string that was based on with tokens replaced and expressions evaluated.

remarks.para: The default token start and end delimiters are { and } but can be overridden in constructor. All substitution tokens surrounded by and (e.g., {token}) will be immediately replaced with their string equivalents before further expression evaluation. As a result of the expression syntax <, >, =, and ! are reserved expressions symbols; , , and are reserved delimiter symbols. To embed any reserved symbol into the so that it appears in the evaluated result, escape the symbol by prefixing it with a backslash, e.g., \{.

The default expression start and end delimiters are [ and ] but can be overridden in constructor. Expressions are represented in the form of [?expression[result]] and can be nested, e.g. ([?expression1[?expression2[result]]]). Expressions should not contain extraneous white space for proper evaluation. Only simple boolean comparison operations are allowed in expressions, e.g., A=B (or A==B), A!=B (or A<>B), A>B, A>=B, A<B and A<=B - nothing more. Any expression that fails to evaluate will be evaluated as FALSE. Note that if both left (A) and right (B) operands can be parsed as a numeric value then the expression will be numerically evaluated otherwise expression will be a culture-invariant string comparison. Nested expressions are evaluated as cumulative AND operators. There is no defined nesting limit.

Advanced expressions can be parsed using the eval function, e.g., eval{1 + 2}. Eval function expression is delimited by the currently defined token delimiters, { and } by default. The evaluation engine deals with numbers and strings. The typing of numeric literals follow C# standards, suffixes such as d, f and m may be used to explicitly specify the numeric type. If no numeric suffix is provided, the default type of a numeric literal is assumed to be . String literals should be specified using single quotes instead of double quotes, this includes substitution parameters, e.g., eval{'{DeviceAcronym}'.Length + 1}. Advanced evaluation expressions using the eval function are always parsed after common expressions. Eval functions cannot be nested.

member.name: M:GSF.PrecisionTimer.SetMinimumTimerResolution(System.Int32)
member.summary: Requests a minimum resolution for periodic timers such as the .
member.param: Minimum timer resolution, in milliseconds, for the application. A lower value specifies a higher (more accurate) resolution.

remarks.para: Call this function immediately before using the and call immediately after you are finished using the PrecisionTimer. You must match each call to with a call to ClearMinimumTimerResolution specifying the same minimum resolution in both calls. An application can make multiple ClearMinimumTimerResolution calls as long as each call is matched with a call to ClearMinimumTimerResolution. This function affects a global Windows setting. Windows uses the lowest value (that is, highest resolution) requested by any process. Setting a higher resolution can improve the accuracy of time-out intervals in wait functions. However, it can also reduce overall system performance, because the thread scheduler switches tasks more often. High resolutions can also prevent the CPU power management system from entering power-saving modes. See timeBeginPeriod Windows API for more information.
This method is currently ignored under Mono deployments.

member.name: M:GSF.PrecisionTimer.ClearMinimumTimerResolution(System.Int32)
member.summary: Clears a previously set minimum timer resolution established using .
member.param: Minimum timer resolution specified in the previous call to the function.

remarks.para: Call this function immediately after you are finished using the . You must match each call to with a call to , specifying the same minimum resolution in both calls. An application can make multiple SetMinimumTimerResolution calls as long as each call is matched with a call to ClearMinimumTimerResolution.
This method is currently ignored under Mono deployments.

member.name: T:GSF.Annotations.NotifyPropertyChangedInvocatorAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the method is contained in a type that implements interface and this method is used to notify that some property value changed
member.remarks:
The method should be non-static and conform to one of the supported signatures:
NotifyChanged(string)
NotifyChanged(params string[])
NotifyChanged{T}(Expression{Func{T}})
NotifyChanged{T,U}(Expression{Func{T,U}})
SetProperty{T}(ref T, T, string)

member.name: T:GSF.Annotations.ContractAnnotationAttribute
member.summary: Describes dependency between method input and output
member.syntax:
Function Definition Table syntax:
FDT ::= FDTRow [;FDTRow]*
FDTRow ::= Input => Output | Output <= Input
Input ::= ParameterName: Value [, Input]*
Output ::= [ParameterName: Value]* {halt|stop|void|nothing|Value}
Value ::= true | false | null | notnull | canbenull
If method has single input parameter, it's name could be omitted.
Using halt (or void/nothing, which is the same) for method output means that the methos doesn't return normally.
canbenull annotation is only applicable for output parameters.
You can use multiple [ContractAnnotation] for each FDT row, or use single attribute with rows separated by semicolon.

item.code: [ContractAnnotation("halt <= condition: false")] public void Assert(bool condition, string text) // regular assertion method
[ContractAnnotation("s:null => true")] public bool IsNullOrEmpty(string s) // string.IsNullOrEmpty()
[ContractAnnotation("s:null=>false; =>true,result:notnull; =>false, result:null")] public bool TryParse(string s, out Person result)

member.summary: Combines a dictionary of key-value pairs in to a string.
member.param: Dictionary of key-value pairs.
Character that delimits one key-value pair from another (e.g. ';').
Character that delimits a key from its value (e.g. '=').
Optional character that marks the start of a value such that value could contain other or characters (e.g., "{").
Optional character that marks the end of a value such that value could contain other or characters (e.g., "}").
member.returns: A string of key-value pairs.
member.remarks: Values will be escaped within and to contain nested key/value pair expressions like the following: normalKVP=-1; nestedKVP={p1=true; p2=0.001}, when either the or are detected in the value of the key/value pair.

member.name: M:GSF.StringExtensions.ParseKeyValuePairs(System.String,System.Char,System.Char,System.Char,System.Char,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Parses key/value pair expressions from a string. Parameter pairs are delimited by and multiple pairs separated by . Supports encapsulated nested expressions.
member.param: String containing key/value pair expressions to parse.
Character that delimits one key/value pair from another.
Character that delimits key from value.
Optional character that marks the start of a value such that value could contain other or characters.
Optional character that marks the end of a value such that value could contain other or characters.
Flag determines whether duplicates are ignored. If flag is set to false an will be thrown when all key parameters are not unique.
member.returns: Dictionary of key/value pairs.

remarks.para: Parses a string containing key/value pair expressions (e.g., "localPort=5001; transportProtocol=UDP; interface=0.0.0.0"). This method treats all "keys" as case-insensitive. Nesting of key/value pair expressions is allowed by encapsulating the value using the and values (e.g., "dataChannel={Port=-1;Clients=localhost:8800}; commandChannel={Port=8900}; dataFormat=FloatingPoint;"). There must be one for each encountered in the value or a will be thrown. Multiple levels of nesting is supported. If the flag is set to false an will be thrown when all key parameters are not unique. Note that keys within nested expressions are considered separate key/value pair strings and are not considered when checking for duplicate keys.

member.exception: value is null.
All delimiters must be unique -or- all keys must be unique when is set to false.
Total nested key/value pair expressions are mismatched -or- encountered before .

member.name: T:GSF.Threading.InterprocessLock
member.summary: Defines helper methods related to inter-process locking.

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.InterprocessLock.GetNamedMutex(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets a uniquely named inter-process associated with the running application, typically used to detect whether an instance of the application is already running.
member.param: Indicates whether to generate a different name for the dependent upon the user running the application.
member.returns: A uniquely named inter-process specific to the application; is created if it does not exist.

remarks.para: This function uses a hash of the assembly's GUID when creating the , if it is available. If it is not available, it uses a hash of the simple name of the assembly. Although the name is hashed to help guarantee uniqueness, it is still entirely possible that another application may use that name with the same hashing algorithm to generate its name. Therefore, it is best to ensure that the is defined in the AssemblyInfo of your application.

The created is "Global" meaning that it will be accessible to all active application sessions including terminal service sessions. This is accomplished internally by prefixing the name with "Global\". Do not use this helper function if you need to create a specifically named or non-global , such as when you need to interact with another application using a that does not use this function.

member.exception: The named mutex exists, but the user does not have the minimum needed security access rights to use it.

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.InterprocessLock.GetNamedMutex(System.String)
member.summary: Gets a uniquely named inter-process associated with the specified that identifies a source object needing concurrency locking.
member.param: Identifying name of source object needing concurrency locking (e.g., a path and file name).
member.returns: A uniquely named inter-process specific to ; is created if it does not exist.

remarks.para: This function uses a hash of the when creating the , not the actual - this way restrictions on the length do not need to be a user concern. All processes needing an inter-process need to use this same function to ensure access to the same .
The can be a string of any length (must not be empty, null or white space) and is not case-sensitive. All hashes of the used to create the global are first converted to lower case.

The created is "Global" meaning that it will be accessible to all active application sessions including terminal service sessions. This is accomplished internally by prefixing the name with "Global\"; it is not necessary for the user to be concerned with the length or contents of the in this method as long as the same is used for each application. Do not use this helper function if you need to create a specifically named or non-global , such as when you need to interact with another application using a that does not use this function.

member.exception: Argument cannot be empty, null or white space.
The named mutex exists, but the user does not have the minimum needed security access rights to use it.

Although the name is hashed to help guarantee uniqueness, it is still entirely possible that another application may use that name with the same hashing algorithm to generate its name. The created is "Global" meaning that it will be accessible to all active application sessions including terminal service sessions. This is accomplished internally by prefixing the name with "Global\". Do not use this helper function if you need to create a specifically named or non-global , such as when you need to interact with another application using a that does not use this function.

member.exception: The named semaphore exists, but the user does not have the minimum needed security access rights to use it.

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.InterprocessReaderWriterLock.EnterReadLock
member.summary: Tries to enter the lock in read mode.
member.remarks: Upon successful acquisition of a read lock, use the finally block of a try/finally statement to call . One should be called for each or .

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.InterprocessReaderWriterLock.EnterWriteLock
member.summary: Tries to enter the lock in write mode.
member.remarks: Upon successful acquisition of a write lock, use the finally block of a try/finally statement to call . One should be called for each or .

member.summary: Exits read mode and returns the prior read lock count.
member.remarks: Upon successful acquisition of a read lock, use the finally block of a try/finally statement to call . One should be called for each or .

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.InterprocessReaderWriterLock.ExitWriteLock
member.summary: Exits write mode.
member.remarks: Upon successful acquisition of a write lock, use the finally block of a try/finally statement to call . One should be called for each or .

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.InterprocessReaderWriterLock.TryEnterReadLock(System.Int32)
member.summary: Tries to enter the lock in read mode, with an optional time-out.
member.param: The number of milliseconds to wait, or -1 () to wait indefinitely.
member.returns: true if the calling thread entered read mode, otherwise, false.

remarks.para: Upon successful acquisition of a read lock, use the finally block of a try/finally statement to call . One should be called for each or .
Note that this function may wait as long as 2 * since the function first waits for synchronous access to the semaphore, then waits again on an available semaphore slot.

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.InterprocessReaderWriterLock.TryEnterWriteLock(System.Int32)
member.summary: Tries to enter the lock in write mode, with an optional time-out.
member.param: The number of milliseconds to wait, or -1 () to wait indefinitely.
member.returns: true if the calling thread entered write mode, otherwise, false.

remarks.para: Upon successful acquisition of a write lock, use the finally block of a try/finally statement to call . One should be called for each or .
Note that this function may wait as long as 2 * since the function first waits for synchronous access to the semaphore, then waits again on an available semaphore slot.

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.ManagedThread.Join(System.TimeSpan)

member.name: T:GSF.Threading.ManagedThreadPool
member.summary: Defines a managed thread pool
member.remarks: This class works like the normal thread pool but provides the benefit of automatic tracking of queued threads through the ManagedThreads collection, returns a reference to the queued thread with the ability to dequeue and/or abort, total thread runtime and the ability to run the queued thread in an alternate execution context

member.returns: Reference to queued thread
member.remarks: This differs from the normal thread pool QueueUserWorkItem function in that it does not return a success value determing if item was queued, but rather a reference to to the managed thread that was actually placed on the queue.

member.name: T:GSF.Threading.DedicatedSynchronizedOperation
member.summary: A synchronized operation that uses its own dedicated thread.
member.remarks: The action performed by the is executed on its own dedicated thread when running the operation asynchronously. When running on its own thread, the action is executed in a tight loop until all pending operations have been completed. This type of synchronized operation should be preferred if operations may take a long time, block the thread, or put it to sleep. It is also recommended to prefer this type of operation if the speed of the operation is not critical or if completion of the operation is critical, such as when saving data to a file.

member.summary: Represents an operation that cannot run while it is already in progress.

member.summary: Gets a value to indicate whether the synchronized operation is currently executing its action.

member.summary: Gets a value to indiate whether the synchronized operation has an additional operation that is pending execution after the currently running action has completed.

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.ISynchronizedOperation.Run
member.summary: Executes the action on this thread or marks the operation as pending if the operation is already running.

remarks.para: When the operation is marked as pending, it will run again after the operation that is currently running has completed. This is useful if an update has invalidated the operation that is currently running and will therefore need to be run again.

This method does not guarantee that control will be returned to the thread that called it. If other threads continuously mark the operation as pending, this thread will continue to run the operation indefinitely.

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.ISynchronizedOperation.TryRun
member.summary: Attempts to execute the action on this thread. Does nothing if the operation is already running.
member.remarks: This method does not guarantee that control will be returned to the thread that called it. If other threads continuously mark the operation as pending, this thread will continue to run the operation indefinitely.

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.ISynchronizedOperation.RunOnce
member.summary: Executes the action on this thread or marks the operation as pending if the operation is already running.
member.remarks: When the operation is marked as pending, it will run again after the operation that is currently running has completed. This is useful if an update has invalidated the operation that is currently running and will therefore need to be run again.

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.ISynchronizedOperation.RunOnceAsync
member.summary: Executes the action on another thread or marks the operation as pending if the operation is already running.
member.remarks: When the operation is marked as pending, it will run again after the operation that is currently running has completed. This is useful if an update has invalidated the operation that is currently running and will therefore need to be run again.

member.name: T:GSF.Threading.LogicalThread
member.summary: Represents a thread of execution to which actions can be dispatched from other threads.

remarks.para: This class provides a simple alternative to synchronization primitives such as wait handles and locks. Actions dispatched to a logical thread will be processed synchronously as though it was executed as consecutive method calls. All such actions can be dispatched from any thread in the system so method calls coming from multiple threads can be easily synchronized without locks, loops, wait handles, or timeouts.

Note that the implements its own thread pool to execute tasks pushed to logical threads. Executing long-running processes or using synchronization primitives with high contention or long timeouts can hinder the logical thread scheduler's ability to schedule the actions of other logical threads. Like other thread pool implementations, you can mitigate this by increasing the maximum thread count of the logical thread scheduler, however it is recommended to avoid using synchronization primitives and instead synchronize those operations by running them as separate actions on the same logical thread.

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.LogicalThreadOperation.RunOnce
member.summary: Executes the action on the current thread or marks the operation as pending if the operation is already running.
member.remarks: When the operation is marked as pending, it will run again at the next call to . This can be useful if an update to an object's state has invalidated the operation that is currently running and will therefore need to be run again.

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.LogicalThreadOperation.RunOnceAsync
member.summary: Executes the action on another thread or marks the operation as pending if the operation is already running.
member.remarks: When the operation is marked as pending, it will run again at the next call to . This can be useful if an update to an object's state has invalidated the operation that is currently running and will therefore need to be run again.

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.LogicalThreadOperation.TryRunOnce
member.summary: Attempts to execute the action on the current thread. Does nothing if the operation is already running.

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.LogicalThreadOperation.TryRunOnceAsync
member.summary: Attempts to execute the action on another thread. Does nothing if the operation is already running.

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.LogicalThreadOperation.RunIfPending
member.summary: Starts the operation over at the beginning if the operation is pending or sets the operation state back to not running so it can run again.
member.remarks: This method must be called at the end of an operation in order to set the state of the operation back to running or not running so that the operation can run again. The existence of this method makes this implementation different from other synchronized operations in that it requires more diligence on the user's part to signal when the operation is complete. In turn, this allows the user to implement complex operations that may involve asynchronous loops and signaling patterns that would not be possible with the interface.

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.LogicalThreadOperation.ExecuteAction(System.Action)
member.summary: Executes an action once on the current thread.
member.param: to run on current thread.
member.remarks: This method provides exception handling for the action passed into this method with a couple of guarantees. The first is that regardless of what thread is executing the action passed into this method, the exception will be raised on the thread that the logical operation runs on. The second is that the RunIfPending method will be called if an exception does occur in the given action.

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.LogicalThreadOperation.RequeueAction(System.Int32)
member.summary: If the operation is running, the action has yet to be executed, and the given priority level differs from the queued action's priority level, this method will requeue the action at the given priority level.
member.param: The priority at which the current operation should be requeued.

member.name: T:GSF.Threading.LongSynchronizedOperation
member.summary: Represents a long-running synchronized operation that cannot run while it is already in progress.
member.remarks: The action performed by the is executed on its own dedicated thread when running the operation asynchronously. When running on its own thread, the action is executed in a tight loop until all pending operations have been completed. This type of synchronized operation should be preferred if operations may take a long time, block the thread, or put it to sleep. It is also recommended to prefer this type of operation if the speed of the operation is not critical or if completion of the operation is critical, such as when saving data to a file.

member.name: T:GSF.Threading.NamespaceDoc
member.summary: Contains classes used to define managed threads that can be used for debugging threads by providing automatic tracking, total thread runtime and the ability to run threads in alternate execution contexts.

member.name: T:GSF.Threading.LoadingAdjustedTimestamp
member.summary: This will provide the user with a timestamp based upon system loading. This timestamp will only move forward in time and may advance rapidly when trying to catch up with system time.
member.remarks: The purpose for this class is to allow LagTime values to dynamically adjust based on perceived system performance. There were issues where the system would have multi second delays introduced based on exception handling or long garbage collection cycles that would cause all measurements to arrive outside the typical system lag time. This class attempts to detect when these events occur and provide increased lag time during these windows.

member.name: E:GSF.Threading.LoadingAdjustedTimestamp.OnHighLoad
member.summary: This event will be raised when the idle thread is falling behind, but the real-time thread is keeping up. This should only be used by certain diagnostics code to dump the current thread pool work items.

member.name: T:GSF.Threading.ReaderWriterSpinLock
member.summary: Represents a fast, lightweight reader/writer lock that uses spinning to perform locking. No recursive acquires or upgradable locks are allowed (i.e., all entered locks must be exited before entering another lock).
member.remarks: This reader/writer lock uses to spin the CPU instead of engaging event based locking. As a result it should only be used in cases where lock times are expected to be very small, reads are very frequent and writes are rare. If hold times for write locks can be lengthy, it will be better to use instead to avoid unnecessary CPU utilization due to spinning incurred by waiting reads.

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.ReaderWriterSpinLock.EnterWriteLock
member.summary: Enters the lock in write mode.
member.remarks: Upon successful acquisition of a write lock, use the finally block of a try/finally statement to call . One should be called for each .

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.ReaderWriterSpinLock.ExitWriteLock
member.summary: Exits write mode.

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.ReaderWriterSpinLock.EnterReadLock
member.summary: Enters the lock in read mode.
member.remarks: Upon successful acquisition of a read lock, use the finally block of a try/finally statement to call . One should be called for each .

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.ReaderWriterSpinLock.ExitReadLock
member.summary: Exits read mode.
member.exception: Cannot exit read lock when there are no readers.

member.summary: For foreground threads, a shutdown handler is registered to dispose of the Thread so it doesn't keep the process running. However, for the Logger, shutting down this thread will prevent shutdown messages from showing up in the logger. By calling this method, it declares that the coder will dispose of this class when it is finished and does not want the Shutdown handler to do it.

This method is safe to call from any thread, including the worker thread. If disposed, this method will no nothing.

member.name: T:GSF.Threading.ShortSynchronizedOperation
member.summary: Represents a short-running synchronized operation that cannot run while it is already in progress.
member.remarks: The action performed by the is executed on the when running the operation asynchronously. When the operation is set to pending, the action is executed in an asynchronous loop on the thread pool until all pending operations have been completed. Since the action is executed on the thread pool, it is best if it can be executed quickly, without blocking the thread or putting it to sleep. If completion of the operation is critical, such as when saving data to a file, this type of operation should not be used since thread pool threads are background threads and will not prevent the program from ending before the operation is complete.

member.summary: Represents a timer class that will group registered timer event callbacks that operate on the same interval in order to optimize thread pool queuing.

remarks.para: Externally the operations similar to the . Internally the timer pools callbacks with the same into a single timer where each callback is executed on the same thread, per instance of the .

member.name: T:GSF.Threading.SynchronizedOperationBase
member.summary: Base class for operations that cannot run while they is already in progress.
member.remarks: This class handles the synchronization between the methods defined in the interface. Implementers should only need to implement the method to provide a mechanism for executing the action on a separate thread.

member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class.
member.param: The action to be performed during this operation.

member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class.
member.param: The action to be performed during this operation.
The action to be performed if an exception is thrown from the action.

member.name: P:GSF.Threading.SynchronizedOperationBase.IsRunning
member.summary: Gets a value to indicate whether the synchronized operation is currently executing its action.

member.name: P:GSF.Threading.SynchronizedOperationBase.IsPending
member.summary: Gets a value to indiate whether the synchronized operation has an additional operation that is pending execution after the currently running action has completed.

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.SynchronizedOperationBase.Run
member.summary: Executes the action on this thread or marks the operation as pending if the operation is already running.

remarks.para: When the operation is marked as pending, it will run again after the operation that is currently running has completed. This is useful if an update has invalidated the operation that is currently running and will therefore need to be run again.

This method does not guarantee that control will be returned to the thread that called it. If other threads continuously mark the operation as pending, this thread will continue to run the operation indefinitely.

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.SynchronizedOperationBase.TryRun
member.summary: Attempts to execute the action on this thread. Does nothing if the operation is already running.
member.remarks: This method does not guarantee that control will be returned to the thread that called it. If other threads continuously mark the operation as pending, this thread will continue to run the operation indefinitely.

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.SynchronizedOperationBase.RunOnce
member.summary: Executes the action on this thread or marks the operation as pending if the operation is already running.
member.remarks: When the operation is marked as pending, it will run again after the operation that is currently running has completed. This is useful if an update has invalidated the operation that is currently running and will therefore need to be run again.

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.SynchronizedOperationBase.RunOnceAsync
member.summary: Executes the action on another thread or marks the operation as pending if the operation is already running.
member.remarks: When the operation is marked as pending, it will run again after the operation that is currently running has completed. This is useful if an update has invalidated the operation that is currently running and will therefore need to be run again.

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.SynchronizedOperationBase.TryRunOnce
member.summary: Attempts to execute the action on this thread. Does nothing if the operation is already running.

member.name: M:GSF.Threading.SynchronizedOperationBase.TryRunOnceAsync
member.summary: Attempts to execute the action on another thread. Does nothing if the operation is already running.

member.summary: Executes the action once on the current thread.

member.summary: For foreground threads, a shutdown handler is registered to dispose of the Thread so it doesn't keep the process running. However, for the Logger, shutting down this thread will prevent shutdown messages from showing up in the logger. member.name: T:GSF.ReusableObjectPool`1
member.summary: Represents a reusable object pool that can be used by an application.

remarks.para: Object pooling can offer a significant performance boost in some scenarios. It is most effective when the cost of construction is high and/or the rate of instantiation is high.

This object pool is statically created at application startup, one per type, and is available for all components and classes within an application domain. Every time you need to use an object, you take one from the pool, use it, then return it to the pool when done. This process can be much faster than creating a new object every time you need to use one.

If the pool objects do not implement you can still use the object pool, but it will be very imporant to return the object to the pool when you are finished using it. If you are using an object scoped within a method, make sure to use a try/finally so that you can take the object within the try and return the object within the finally. If you are using an object as a member scoped class field, make sure you use the standard dispose pattern and return the object during the method call. In this mode you will also need to manually initialze your object after you get it from the pool to reset its state.

member.typeparam: Type of object to pool.

member.name: M:GSF.ReusableObjectPool`1.TakeObject
member.summary: Gets an object from the pool, or creates a new one if no pool items are available.
member.returns: An available object from the pool, or a new one if no pool items are available.
member.remarks: If type of implements , the pool will attach to the item's event such that the object can be automatically restored to the pool upon . It will be up to class implementors to make sure makes the class ready for use as this method will always be called for an object being taken from the pool.

member.name: M:GSF.ReusableObjectPool`1.ReturnObject(`0)
member.summary: Returns object to the pool.
member.param: Reference to the object being returned.
member.remarks: If type of implements , the pool will automatically return the item to the pool when the event is raised, usually when the object's method is called.

member.name: M:GSF.ReusableObjectPool`1.Clear
member.summary: Releases all the objects currently cached in the pool.

member.summary: Allocates the pool to the desired .
member.param: Desired pool size.
member.exception: Pool must at least be one.

member.name: M:GSF.ReusableObjectPool`1.GetPoolSize
member.summary: Gets the number of items currently contained in the pool.
member.returns: The size of the pool.

member.name: F:GSF.ReusableObjectPool`1.Default
member.summary: Default static instance which can be shared throughout the application.

member.name: T:GSF.Scheduling.NamespaceDoc
member.summary: Contains classes used to schedule operations using standard UNIX crontab syntax.

member.name: T:GSF.Scheduling.Schedule
member.summary: Represents a schedule defined using UNIX crontab syntax.

remarks.para: Operators:

There are several ways of specifying multiple date/time values in a field:
The comma (',') operator specifies a list of values, for example: "1,3,4,7,8"
The dash ('-') operator specifies a range of values, for example: "1-6", which is equivalent to "1,2,3,4,5,6"
The asterisk ('*') operator specifies all possible values for a field. For example, an asterisk in the hour time field would be equivalent to 'every hour' (subject to matching other specified fields).
The slash ('/') operator (called "step"), which can be used to skip a given number of values. For example, "*/3" in the hour time field is equivalent to "0,3,6,9,12,15,18,21". So "*" specifies 'every hour' but the "*/3" means only those hours divisible by 3.
Fields:
Each of the patterns from the first five fields may be either * (an asterisk), which matches all legal values, or a list of elements separated by commas.
See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cron for more information.

member.name: M:GSF.Security.Cryptography.Cipher.FlushCache(System.Int32)
member.summary: Blocks current thread and waits for any pending save of local system key cache to complete.
member.param: The number of milliseconds to wait, or (-1) to wait indefinitely.

remarks.para: This method only needs to be used if crypto cache changes could be pending during application shutdown (i.e., executing ciphers with new keys that have not been saved, using existing keys does not queue crypto cache updates) to ensure keys are flushed before exit.

For most applications it is expected that this method would be rarely needed. However, possible usage scenarios would include:
Writing an application that establishes crypto keys where application lifetime would be very short (i.e., run, create keys, exit).
Creating new crypto keys during application shutdown (i.e., performing ciphers with non-existing keys at shutdown).

member.summary: Returns comparison results of two binary arrays.
member.param: Source array.
Other array to compare to array.
member.remarks: Note that if both arrays are null the arrays will be considered equal. If one array is null and the other array is not null, the non-null array will be considered larger. member.name: T:GSF.BigEndian
member.summary: Defines a set of big-endian byte order interoperability functions.
member.remarks: This class is setup to support aggressive in-lining of big endian conversions. Bounds will not be checked as part of this function call, if bounds are violated, the exception will be thrown at the level.

member.exception: value is null.
startIndex is less than zero or greater than the length of value minus 1.

member.summary: Defines extension functions related to character manipulation.

member.name: M:GSF.CharExtensions.RegexEncode(System.Char)
member.summary: Encodes the specified Unicode character in proper Regular Expression format.
member.param: Unicode character to encode in Regular Expression format.
member.returns: Specified Unicode character in proper Regular Expression format.

member.name: M:GSF.CharExtensions.IsWordTerminator(System.Char)
member.summary: Tests a character to determine if it marks the end of a typical English word.
member.param: Input character to check.
member.returns: true if character is a work separator.
member.remarks:
Performs no testing for ASCII codes > 127.
Does not separate words based on punctuation of ' % - _
However does include the angle bracket symbols < > as separators
For reference the standard char tests are:
"IsSperator (1) == simple space (32 or 160) only.
IsPunctuation (23) == . , ! ? : ; " ' [ ] { } ( ) \ / @ % # * & - _ (plus other char's > 127)
IsSymbol (8) == $ + < > = ^ ` ~
IsWhiteSpace (6) == control char's 9 thru 13, plus 32 -- TAB, LF, VT, FF, CR, SP

member.name: M:GSF.CharExtensions.IsNumeric(System.Char)
member.summary: Tests a character to determine if is a common part of a numeric string (digits or one of "+ - , .")
member.param: The character to check.
member.returns: true if numeric character.

member.name: M:GSF.CharExtensions.IsAnyOf(System.Char,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Char})
member.summary: Determines if a character matches any character in a sent array.
member.param: The character to check.
The array of characters to test.
member.returns: Boolean value indicating a that the character is in the array.

member.name: M:GSF.CharExtensions.IsInRange(System.Char,System.Char,System.Char)
member.summary: Tests a character to determine if it is between a specified character range
member.param: Input character to process.

End of range character.
member.returns: true is the character is within the range.

member.name: T:GSF.Int24
member.summary: Represents a 3-byte, 24-bit signed integer.

remarks.para: This class behaves like most other intrinsic signed integers but allows a 3-byte, 24-bit integer implementation that is often found in many digital-signal processing arenas and different kinds of protocol parsing. A signed 24-bit integer is typically used to save storage space on disk where its value range of -8388608 to 8388607 is sufficient, but the signed Int16 value range of -32768 to 32767 is too small.

This structure uses an Int32 internally for storage and most other common expected integer functionality, so using a 24-bit integer will not save memory. However, if the 24-bit signed integer range (-8388608 to 8388607) suits your data needs you can save disk space by only storing the three bytes that this integer actually consumes. You can do this by calling the Int24.GetBytes function to return a three byte binary array that can be serialized to the desired destination and then calling the Int24.GetValue function to restore the Int24 value from those three bytes.

All the standard operators for the Int24 have been fully defined for use with both Int24 and Int32 signed integers; you should find that without the exception Int24 can be compared and numerically calculated with an Int24 or Int32. Necessary casting should be minimal and typical use should be very simple - just as if you are using any other native signed integer.

member.name: F:GSF.Int24.BitMask
member.summary: High byte bit-mask used when a 24-bit integer is stored within a 32-bit integer. This field is constant.

member.name: M:GSF.Int24.GetBytes
member.summary: Returns the Int24 value as an array of three bytes.
member.returns: An array of bytes with length 3.

remarks.para: You can use this function in-lieu of a System.BitConverter.GetBytes function.
Bytes will be returned in endian order of currently executing process architecture (little-endian on Intel platforms).

member.name: M:GSF.Int24.TryParse(System.String,GSF.Int24@)
member.summary: Converts the string representation of a number to its 24-bit signed integer equivalent. A return value indicates whether the conversion succeeded or failed.
member.param: A string containing a number to convert.

When this method returns, contains the 24-bit signed integer value equivalent to the number contained in s, if the conversion succeeded, or zero if the conversion failed. The conversion fails if the s parameter is null, is not of the correct format, or represents a number less than Int24.MinValue or greater than Int24.MaxValue. This parameter is passed uninitialized.
member.returns: true if s was converted successfully; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:GSF.Int24.TryParse(System.String,System.Globalization.NumberStyles,System.IFormatProvider,GSF.Int24@)

When this method returns, contains the 24-bit signed integer value equivalent to the number contained in s, if the conversion succeeded, or zero if the conversion failed. The conversion fails if the s parameter is null, is not in a format compliant with style, or represents a number less than Int24.MinValue or greater than Int24.MaxValue. member.returns: true if s was converted successfully; otherwise, false.

member.remarks: There is no defined Int24 type code and since an Int24 will easily fit inside an Int32, the Int32 type code is returned.

member.name: T:GSF.LittleEndian
member.summary: Defines a set of little-endian byte order interoperability functions.
member.remarks: This class is setup to support aggressive in-lining of little endian conversions. Bounds will not be checked as part of this function call, if bounds are violated, the exception will be thrown at the level.

member.name: T:GSF.NtpTimeTag
member.summary: Represents a standard Network Time Protocol (NTP) timetag.
member.remarks: As recommended by RFC-2030, all NTP timestamps earlier than 3h 14m 08s UTC on 20 January 1968 are reckoned from 6h 28m 16s UTC on 7 February 2036. This gives the class a functioning range of 1968-01-20 03:14:08 to 2104-02-26 09:42:23.

member.name: M:GSF.Reflection.AssemblyExtensions.TryLoadAllReferences(System.Reflection.Assembly)
member.summary: Recursively attempts to load all assemblies referenced from the given assembly.
member.param: The assembly whose references are to be loaded.
member.returns: true if the references were successfully loaded; false otherwise.
member.remarks: If an object is created from a type that is loaded from an assembly, and if that assembly's references fail to load during instantiation, an exception may be thrown from both the constructor and the finalizer of the object that was instantiated. This method allows us to ensure that all referenced assemblies can be loaded before attempting to instantiate a type from that assembly.

member.name: T:GSF.ShortTime
member.summary: Represents a high resolution time that is very granular but may drift if trying to accurately measure long time durations (Such as hours). This time is not adjusted with changes to the system clock. Typical clock drifts by about 2-3 ms per minute as apposed to 0.4ms per minute for standard DateTime.
member.remarks: Call times are about 40+ million calls per second.

member.name: T:GSF.Ticks
member.summary: Represents an instant in time, or time period, as a 64-bit signed integer with a value that is expressed as the number of 100-nanosecond intervals that have elapsed since 12:00:00 midnight, January 1, 0001.

remarks.para: can represent an "instant in time" and therefore can be used exactly like a . The difference between and is that is essentially a long integer (i.e., an ) which represents the number of ticks that have elapsed since 12:00:00 midnight, January 1, 0001 with each tick having a resolution of 100-nanoseconds. You would use in places where you needed to directly represent time in high-resolution, i.e., time with sub-second accuracy, using an object that will act like a long integer but handle time conversions. can also represent a "time period" (e.g., the number of ticks elapsed since a process started) and thus can also be used like a ; when used in this manner the method can be used to convert the value into a handy textual representation of elapsed years, days, hours, minutes and seconds or sub-seconds.

This class behaves just like an representing a time in ticks; it is implicitly castable to and from an and therefore can be generally used "as" an Int64 directly. It is also implicitly castable to and from a , a , an and a .

member.summary: Returns a floor-aligned sub-second distribution timestamp for given .
member.param: Timestamp to align.
Samples per second to use for distribution.
Defines the time resolution to use when aligning to its proper distribution timestamp.
member.returns: A floor-aligned sub-second distribution timestamp for given .
member.remarks:
Time resolution value is typically a power of 10 based on the number of ticks per the desired resolution. The following table defines common resolutions and their respective values:
Resolution Time Resolution Value
Seconds
Milliseconds
Microseconds
Ticks 0
If source timestamps have variation, i.e., they are not aligned within common distributions, the can be adjusted to include slack to accommodate the variance. When including slack in the time resolution, the value will depend on the , for example: you could use 330,000 for 30 samples per second, 160,000 for 60 samples per second, and 80,000 for 120 samples per second. Actual slack value may need to be more or less depending on the size of the source timestamp variation.

member.name: T:GSF.UInt24
member.summary: Represents a 3-byte, 24-bit unsigned integer.

remarks.para: This class behaves like most other intrinsic unsigned integers but allows a 3-byte, 24-bit integer implementation that is often found in many digital-signal processing arenas and different kinds of protocol parsing. An unsigned 24-bit integer is typically used to save storage space on disk where its value range of 0 to 16777215 is sufficient, but the unsigned Int16 value range of 0 to 65535 is too small.

This structure uses an UInt32 internally for storage and most other common expected integer functionality, so using a 24-bit integer will not save memory. However, if the 24-bit unsigned integer range (0 to 16777215) suits your data needs you can save disk space by only storing the three bytes that this integer actually consumes. You can do this by calling the UInt24.GetBytes function to return a three byte binary array that can be serialized to the desired destination and then calling the UInt24.GetValue function to restore the UInt24 value from those three bytes.

All the standard operators for the UInt24 have been fully defined for use with both UInt24 and UInt32 unsigned integers; you should find that without the exception UInt24 can be compared and numerically calculated with an UInt24 or UInt32. Necessary casting should be minimal and typical use should be very simple - just as if you are using any other native unsigned integer.

member.name: T:GSF.Units.EE.SignalKind
member.summary: Fundamental signal type enumeration for common EE measurements that represents a kind of signal, not an explicit type.

remarks.para: This enumeration represents the basic type of a signal used to suffix a formatted signal reference. When used in context along with an optional index the fundamental signal type will identify a signal's location within a frame of data (see ).
Contrast this to the enumeration which further defines an explicit type for a signal (e.g., a voltage or current type for an angle).

When this method returns, contains the value equivalent to the number contained in s, if the conversion succeeded, or zero if the conversion failed.
